Archives, Future of Coding Community, #introduce-yourself, index

# Hemi Edwards 2025-09-17 07:10 #
Hello everyone,

My name is Hemi Edwards. I'm a computing and technology enthusiast from Aotearoa/New Zealand. I am indigenous and belong to the Rongowhakaata tribe of the Maori. We occupy our ancestral lands on the East Coast of Aotearoa/New Zealand, though we have lost much in the process of colonization. We have too gained much from our engagement with the rest of the world. For most of us our primary language is English but there have been efforts to revitalize our indigenous language of Te Reo Maori, for the last 50 years. Many other indigenous peoples see our success as an inspiration for the rejuvenation of their own traditional languages and I believe that digital technologies offer much to support this mission. Speaking English grants us opportunities to meaningfully engage with the wider work, especially in forums like this where we can learn about new possibilities and ways to think and interact with the physical world.

I have been familiar with Bret Victor's work for some years now and have been excited about the potential for these new approaches to make computer interactions more meaningful, embodied, and accessible than currently. This is really important especially when it comes to economically deprived and socially marginalized communities like my people, who lost much from colonization and whose experience in the traditional school system was specifically intended to stunt our development as individuals and as a people. This has had ongoing generational impacts for my people. Language revitalization is just one aspect of current efforts to close the gaps in terms of learning achievement, equitable economic participation, and development of personal and social capacity.
5 comments
# daniel g. siegel 2025-09-09 06:56 #
Hi! I’ve been hanging around here for a while and listening to the FoC Podcast, so I thought it’s time to finally introduce myself :slightly_smiling_face: I’m Daniel. I have a background in computer science and psychology, and over the years I’ve worked across Free & Open Source software (most notably with the GNOME project). I’ve been in the startup world, spent a few years in emerging tech consulting at Accenture, and these days I’m an independent consultant, speaker, and writer.

My work and philosophy are deeply rooted in the insights of visionaries like Doug Engelbart, Alan Kay, Neil Postman, James Burke, Joseph Weizenbaum, and Bret Victor. Their pioneering spirit, especially the idea that technology should not replace humans, but amplify human capabilities, is what guides my work.

Most recently, I founded the Big Idea Initiative - a playground for ideas that amplify our human capabilities and raise our collective intelligence.

We’re always looking for ideas, contributions, and people who want to explore new ways of thinking, building, and connecting. If you’ve got a half-baked thought, an experiment, or just curiosity - you’re very welcome to share and shape it with us.

You can find more here: https://www.bigideainitiative.org/
8 comments
# Nodar 2025-09-08 09:25 #
Hi all, I'm Nodar. I've been generally aware of the future of code (now feeling of computing) for a couple of years now but only just now got around to joining the Slack. My first coding experience was in HyperCard in the late 90s. Now days for development and personal work I'm terminal/keyboard focused over GUIs (or at least point & click, mouse-oriented input), but still develop GUIs for end users, and for myself I still carry a deep interest in better interfaces, and their ability to reduce the friction and bandwidth between thought and computation.

Particularly interested in the evolution of ideas around literate programming, and also ways of extending the computational notebook paradigm.

• learn-orca - a playground for learning/playing the orca midi sequencer online

# Arcade Wise 2025-07-24 10:08 #
Hello World! I'm Arcade Wise, 18 and from... I guess the southeastern United States? I've lived all over and college is in Iowa.
Given the mention of college I bet you can figure out that I'm a student, studying Computer Science and German.
I haven't had enough time recently to do much coding, but I think y'all might like my project "I CAN'T BELIEVE IT'S NOT FORTH," a little project to write HTML widgets in a forth-like language.

I've been mainly involved with the folk.computer people, I really think projected AR is a really interesting thing that not enough people have access to. I'm also tangential to the LIMITS (Computing Within Limits) conference, and the larger degrowth-club of Rome movement as a whole.

As for how I got into the FoC community, I was introduced to Ivan and Co. by Lu, whose videos I had watched for a while and met at Strange Loop (RIP).

# Laura Brekelmans 2025-07-22 16:39 #
HELLO! I am Laura Brekelmans, 29 years old and from the Netherlands.
I'm a professional software engineer, and I sometimes dabble in creative coding.

I also published some articles

• This one where I deconstruct a generative art piece by Terebus Volodymyr is still my favorite published work of all time. (note, doesn't work on mobile! Whoops)
• A few years ago I also published an article on the future of coding myself which was somewhat popular at the time.
My interest in the future of coding emerged when I discovered Bret Victor's work about a decade ago at this point (woah). Ever since that I dove deep into history of computer science, have consumed hundreds of hours of Alan Kay, Ted Nelson, Bret Victor, Douglas Engelbart, HARC, Viewpoints research institute, Dan Ingalls, Bill Buxton etcetcetc.
I'm also somewhat active on the Ohm Discord, I think that community might have some overlap with this one! Ohm is a library as well as an ecosystem of tools to make grammars and programming languages.

I often have ideas for meaningful or interesting new ways of doing programming or interacting with programming tools, but I never really felt like I had the room for these ideas to grow larger so not much has come of it (so far!)
When I was still a student I was really active making codepens, generative art, programming language experiments, blog posts and even entire programs as part of a conversation to other programs just because I thought it was cool. A bit later I got into a really deep depression and I've kind of lost my mojo, but I'm sort of trying to find it back again? I've since recovered, gladly, but I'm still feeling the discrepancy between how creative and active I was back then. I hope by joining this community I can reignite some of that passion again :c

I think I learned about this community through Lu Wilson, who has also been really inspiring for me the past year. Thank you for doing your thing Lu!

Edit: Oh and I forgot, I'm working on a realtalk implementation in JS called ma which is available on Github. It's very very early in development, I just work on it every now and then. It's mostly meant for fun, but it works.
# Damian Bemben 2025-07-17 05:00 #
Hi there! I'm Damian,

I'm a professional software developer and a non-professional creative technologist with a background in designing a lot of silly projects for exhibitions, i've got a massive lack of focus, tending to be caught by different whims for creative design based on different projects, finding the right tech to suit certain aspects. I've been quite insular with a lot of my development, especially for festivals, so this year i've been trying to be a bit more open and show off some of my work.

I've realised that there's limits to how much you can learn while being secretive and insular, so really wanted to join a community and connect with others interested in these types of computing! I'm very used to a professional software world where there's a lot less room to play, so it's felt really nice to try and revive some of the passion that brought me into programming in the first place this year.

A couple of my projects:

• NimbyDex - a highly insulting gemini agent with GL mapping frontend that attempts to quantify the "NIMBY"ness of cancelled renewable projects in the UK
• Think Inside The Box - an old festival project that used a mixture of AR and VR to create small teaching moments for different engineering disciplines
• 3D prints with LIDAR data to create little mementos + matchbox buildings for smaller venues with loads of charm. This involved getting really in-depth with blender, mapping + python scripting within blender.
I'm definitely very scattered in the stuff that I make, and i've begun this year to finally start doing lots of talks, got recommended this by Hugh Evans who organises AI Signals! I'm also organising a community within Southampton based around creative coding, so wanted to get more properly involved! This seems like a great community!

# David Aerne 2025-06-30 11:07 #
Hi everyone, I’m David :wave:

I’m a Swiss interaction developer with a strong focus on creative tooling, color, and generative systems. My background spans (frontend) programming, UI/UX, and generative art — especially where these intersect with visual design. These days, I spend a lot of time thinking about how interfaces can better reflect the messy, nonlinear way humans think and work.

Some of my recent-ish work:

- Poline — a library for generative color ramp creation
- RampenSau — an other tool for exploring color ramps
- Gradient Book with Rik Oostenbroek — a collaboration for Paris Photo 2024, exploring code-based gradient manipulation

I found FoC through @Florian Schulz and joined to connect with others exploring alternative paths in computing — especially where creativity, expressiveness, and play intersect with code.

Currently, I’m working on a descriptive design language for color — a way to create semantic and functional links between colors. Kind of a missing bridge between generative color systems and real-world design use.

Looking forward to learning from you all!

Here you may find more info: https://muratkasimov.art/Ya. I think that future of programming is in hands of linear algebra and category theory.

Hey folks, great to be here - it’s a joy to find such a forward thinking, open-minded community. Looking forward to taking a bit more of an active part.

I’ve been working with Clojure, and especially Datomic where I can, for the last few years, with small forays into iOS and (slightly larger excursions) web applications. FP, structural editing and s-expressions are my happy place, mashed up with abusing browsers and CSS to do occasionally surprising things. I amuse myself with generative art pieces when I have time, using quil and trying to keep up with some of Tyler Hobbs’ excellent examples. Owen Schuh is another favourite - really love his work. Suggestions for more brain food are always welcome!

# Ryan Pearl 2025-05-28 15:59 #
Hi, my name's Ryan. I've worked in and around the more corporate low-code/no code space, which isn't always great but I've spent a long time thinking about end user programming. I've also built some tools for LED art, though they've bitrotted slightly by now.

AI coding agents have me simultaneously extremely pessimistic about code as craft and optimistic about expanding what's possible with computers, and I want to figure out how to be on the right side of that line. I'm between jobs and reading a bunch of papers which led me here, and this feels like the sort of place that skews towards optimism.
2 comments
# Hernan Wilkinson 2025-05-21 04:55 #
Hi! my name is Hernán Wilkinson, from Argentina, Smalltalker :slightly_smiling_face: , professor at the FCEyN-UBA, partner at 10Pines and FAST (Argentinean Foundation of Smalltalk).
I’ve implemented LiveTyping for Cuis Smalltalk. LiveTyping collects types while the system is running (in Smalltalk that is all the time, even when programming) and retro-feed that info into de development environment to improve tools such as refactorings, autocomplete, etc. LiveTyping allows you to use development tools as if you were using a statically typed language but in a dynamically typed one, without the burden to define and maintain the types.
I’ve also implemented many refactorings for Cuis Smalltalk and created a distribution called CuisUniversity to teach OO at the university, besides other things.

If you're someone who loves debating the unimaginable and pushing boundaries in tech, let's connect and explore what's possible.

# Steve Krouse 2025-04-24 20:30 #
# Jared M. Smith 2025-04-21 15:20 #
Hi there! :wave: I’m Jared. I’ve been ~lurking~ listening/reading for a while. I found the community via a recommendation from Taylor Troesh when lamenting the end of the Strange Loop conference. I host the Elm Town podcast where I interview folks through their software engineering journeys to understand why they are in the Elm community and how they got there. Sometimes I talk with folks outside of the Elm community when it relates to Elm.

I’m interested in unique perspectives and ideas in humanity, computing and beyond. I’m also interested in the way technology integrates into nature. If this community advances human-computer interaction, I am interested in technology-nature interaction. That is, how to make our technology more in-harmony with nature (sustainable, balanced, and connected). It’s not a binary distinction nor two-dimensional. We come from nature and by extension, so does technology. But we think of ourselves as outside of nature. I’m interested in challenging that assumption in order to enjoy our creations without burning down the house.

# Robin Heggelund Hansen 2025-03-22 23:19 #
Hello:wave:

@Ale tipped me of this community.

I recently announced my «Programming Language for the Future» research project. It’s called Gløgg (Norwegian word for a drink that’s similar to Gluwine, which I was drinking when I created the repo). The project is inspired by Eve (Chris Granger and company), and projects written in it is stored in sqlite files.

Intro blog post: https://git.sr.ht/~robheghan/glogg/tree/main/item/docs/motivation.md

Tutorial: https://git.sr.ht/~robheghan/glogg/tree/main/item/docs/tutorial.md

Repo: https://git.sr.ht/~robheghan/glogg

# Yi-Hung Chou 2025-03-15 13:22 #
Hello everyone, I’m Yi-Hung Chou, a 2nd-year Ph.D. student at UC Irvine. I’m deeply interested in how developers understand and navigate the dynamic aspects of software—whether it’s debugging, running tests, deciding where to write tests, or ad-hocly writing console.log!

Recently, I analyzed a dataset of accidentally pushed console.log statements on GitHub (e.g., console.log("here"), console.log("is this code running")) [paper here] . We hope this dataset and our methods can provide valuable insights for language designers, programming tool developers, and library maintainers—like you—on the challenges developers face in understanding run-time behavior. If you’re attending MSR or ICSE this year in Ottawa, come say hi and check out my talk!

I’m also working on a tool to help developers better organize and make sense of interleaving log outputs from asynchronous and parallel programs. I will definitely share more about it soon in the share-your-work channel.

Shoutout to all the amazing work shared here—I’m excited to read your ideas and get inspired!
1 comments
# killick 2025-03-14 13:58 #
hey everyone! I’m killick, I’ve been a programmer for 15+ years. I work in non-profit orthopedic healthcare. Right now I’m uuubsessed with legacy systems migration (aka been in it for so long I have to justify its value).

questions that haunt me rn:
• why do ppl assume rebuilding from scratch is easier?
• is small incremental migration always more desirable?
• are there any general criteria for picking a migration strategy? (cf Patterns of Legacy Displacement)
• is there a negative correlation between familiarity with a system and the perceived difficulty of migrating it? or vice versa?
anyhow, this is my latest rabbit hole. previous (and evergreen) ones include uiua, coordinate systems, a multi-user simultaneous room-scale development environment, and the indie web.

happy to be here!

# George Powell 2025-03-08 09:02 #
What's up everyone! So happy to have finally joined! I'm George, I am currently working on developing my coding/engineering skills full-time after being employed as a barista for the past year. I studied computer science for several years in Boston, but was deeply unsatisfied with both the general CS curriculum and my own academic performance, so I dropped out to pursue other things. I grew up in Tyngsborough, a tiny town outside Boston, and now live in southern Maine. I've always been a fan of this community and it had a huge influence on my decision to go back to school this coming summer, where I will be studying sociology. I don't think I know anyone from here personally, but Maya Avendaño and of course Maggie Appleton have inspired me for quite a while now.

My first project is a lofi web radio for Byzantine music of the Eastern Orthodox Church, which will be released soon. I'm very excited to meet and learn with others in this community!

Hi new friends, I'm Zeke. I live in Chicago and I love thinking about the future of computing in my spare time. In my day job, I'm a staff engineer at Abridge.

I'm happy to find this space because I've been doing a lot of reflection alone or among friends and it seems like you are doing it together, here.

I've recently been reworking a blog post about the cost of computing over time. It's still a work in progress, and maybe it will be forever, and I'd love to hear what you all think about it.

I'm also doing some personal research projects (like a typescript / prompt IDE in tldraw!). I'd be stoked to talk to folks about that too. But, as a parent of young children, my time is limited so my work moves slowly!

# Harry Sotnick-Hommel 2025-02-27 01:31 #

Since graduating from a software bootcamp, I've worked on several internships and contract roles, but I'm now seeking full-time opportunities as a software/solutions engineer.

Outside of tech, I co-run a charity redirecting unsold supermarket food to food banks (150,000+ meals saved!) and organises sleeping bag distributions for rough sleepers. Last week, we believe we ran the UK's largest sleeping bag handout, providing 380 bags across 8 cities.

# Isaac Carrasco-Ortiz 2025-02-25 08:41 #
Hi everyone! I just joined the community, so it's nice to meet you all. My name is Isaac Carrasco-Ortiz (he/him), and I am the Digital Equity Fellow for the Executive Office of Aging & Independence based in Boston, Massachusetts in the United States. I have been here as an AmeriCorps member, where my role is to help the state agency address digital inequities that exist for older adults throughout the state (poor access to broadband services, poor digital skills, access to respectful technological devices and services that best fit their needs). We've mainly been fighting for this through federal funds that were made available to address the digital divide (funds were given to senior centers and their partners to start or expand digital literacy programming for older adults). However, now that the funds are set to run out, we've been sketching out what role the state agency can play in making technology more respectful and socially conscious of the needs and thoughts of older adults in Massachusetts moving forward. I've been increasingly exploring this relationship between humanity and technology, and it's through some more reading of that that I learned of Douglas Engelbart's Augmenting Human Intellect essay. I thought I'd look more into if other organizations were speaking about this essay, and it's through that search that learned of the Future of Coding, namely the podcast episode that spoke about him and his work (I haven't listened to it yet!).

I hope to become active in this community. If you're in the Boston area and are interested in learning more about what we're up to, just shoot me a message! I should note that my background is not in tech, but rather sociology and systems of oppression. Looking forward to learning more about your work and insights! Thanks y'all :blush:

https://www.linkedin.com/in/isaac-carrasco-ortiz-42639b1aa/
# Padraig Fl 2025-02-25 05:05 #
Hi! I'm Padraig, I'm based in London and mostly work on the frontend (although I'm increasingly keen to get deeper than that...) I don't fully understand what this place is yet but I like the vibes. My interests tend to swing heavily retro gimmick stuff (e.g. I could probably write a blog about children's watches in old Argos catalogs and how they perfectly represent the technologies of the period) so it's debatable how much I can contribute to the future...

My attempts to make positive contributions towards the software dev ecosystem are generally a mix of (in order of importance):
1. making sure websites I work on still work on my mam's phone
2. pushing back in my workplaces against Google Analytics being dumped into absolutely everything everywhere
3. posting literally anything possibly useful I discover about a thing in a public location so others can find it in the future (tbh I think this is arguably the most important one these days...)
4. reviving old abandoned tech either via software (e.g. most recently I reverse engineered an ewaste STEM toy and made a library for it https://github.com/padraigfl/twsu-arcade-coder-esp32 , previously I wrote some tools and documentation to help preservation efforts for the abandonware mixed media card game Dropmix) or just finding personal uses for them (e.g. the FM radio station of rain sounds I've in my flat so our dog can't hear the foxes our neighbour keeps feeding)
5. dumb half-finished proof of concept stuff like my recreation of the Shrek DVD menu (https://github.com/padraigfl/dvd-menu)
Most my social network are extremely non-technical people so it'd be great to get involved in some things with people who know what I'm talking about when I talk about these things (or can tell when I don't know what I'm talking about and call me out!). Should be at the meetup this Friday, not totally sure what to expect but I'm looking forward to it!

www.pdrgf.com/about
# When Leggett 2025-02-18 20:50 #
Hi all! I'm When. I'm excited to participate in discussion here and share ideas. I've been a long time dreamer in what has been possible for the future of code. I've been working in software for over 20 years now and I've always been passionate about empowering people with software, especially those who don't know how to code. I have a degree in both Art and Computer Science, and the intersection between expression, intention, interface, abstraction, and usability has always been of keen interest to me. I mostly found my calling in writing tools that allow other to work at a higher level.

In 2007, I wrote what I believe to be the first ever "reactive javascript framework", at least in the form you see now - client-side templates, data-binding, client-side routing, components etc. I had to do a lot from scratch: module system, template compiler, fine-grained data-binding system. I've been watching the rest of the industry do it wrong ever since (I'm kidding! :stuck_out_tongue_closed_eyes:). It's still in use by the company I built it for (although I don't work there anymore), and it beat out Vue 3 + Vite in a head to head evaluation recently (from what I hear). It currently powers a loan automation system that handles billions of dollars in loans. I was never able to open source it, so I guess y'all have to take my word for it, lol. Happy to talk about it if there's anyone curious. It still has a few tricks I haven't seen in the wild. I've also built a custom workflow engine and business rules system that had a pretty unique architecture and scaled really well (over 500k rules), and actually delivered on the promise of moving a huge amount of logic into the hands of non-programmers (without needing programmers to babysit it). Those are some things I'm most proud of and have deeply informed some of the ideas that I imagine for the "future of coding".

My closest thing to an actual claim to fame was my involvement in the standardization of ES6. I have a name credit associated with breaking the standoff around classes. The "maximally minimal class" proposal was based off of a proposal I made.

These days I've been working on my own vision for the "future of coding". I'm a big fan of Alan Kay and Brett Victor. From Alan Kay, I really love the idea that we need to shift from mechanical to ecological thinking. From Brett Victor I love the concept that the "digital medium" needs a separate concept of "authors/authoring" that is separate from engineering/programming. The fact that programming languages have been a tool for both is part of what holds us back. I'm working on a unique sort of universal IR binary format inspired by DNA, and a programming/modeling language inspired by cellular biology. Happy to chat about any of this stuff, but mostly here to see what everyone else is doing! Looking forward to learning from all the brilliant minds here.
14 comments
# claire speller 2025-02-18 09:33 #
Hello everyone! I'm excited to join this community! I’m a nurse with a strong interest in coding, and I’m eager to learn the basics and start building my skills. As someone coming from a healthcare background, I’m looking to explore how coding can complement my experience, and perhaps open up new career opportunities down the road.
I’m curious to know where to begin and what resources would be best for someone just starting out. Also, I’d love to hear how others taught themselves to code and any tips you have for a beginner. Looking forward to learning from all of you!

# Raghav Agrawal 2025-02-17 08:16 #
> Hi, I'm Raghav Agrawal from Mumbai, India. I work in the diamond trading industry (part of a small family business specializing in loose diamond exports) but I've immersed myself in self-education curating research for design theory, philosophy of technology, media studies, educational theories, philosophy of science, and cognitive science for quite a while. All this culminated into a project idea : A small catalogue of novel edtech interface patterns that introduce a new way of online learning, teaching. I have recently enrolled in an offline UX bootcamp to materialize some of the ideas and was introduced to this group by @Pranav Pramod.
>
> My interest in the tool for thought space is to figure out if we can conceive of entirely new pedagogies via material properties unique to the computing medium instead of replicating linear ways of teaching online like the way LMSes operate, in short interested in novel edtech interfaces

# Bill Budge 2025-02-16 12:28 #
Hi, I'm Bill, and I have been following this group for a while now.

I began programming as a teenager back in the 1970's (first language Autocoder assembly on an IBM 1401 computer.)

I got an Apple II computer in 1979, which led to me dropping out of graduate school and becoming a game programmer. I wrote Pinball Construction Set, probably my main claim to fame. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinball_Construction_Set

After that I had a long career as a programmer working at Apple Computer, Electronic Arts, The 3DO Company, Sony Computer Entertainment, and finally at Google, where I worked on Chrome, Native Client, WebAssembly, and the V8 Javascript compiler and runtime.

I have been interested in building editor-like tools for constructing programs for a long time. Pinball Construction Set allowed users to build their own video pinball games. At Sony, I worked on a set of libraries for building editors which was widely used internally and eventually open-sourced: https://github.com/SonyWWS/ATF. One tool was a node-and-wire realtime procedural audio library, another a Statechart editor.

For the last 10 years I have been working on an editor for diagramming software, using "nodes and wires", but adopting some of the ideas behind Harel Statecharts. I will share this work on that thread.
2 comments
# Guido Contreras Woda 2025-02-07 15:43 #
Hey everyone! :wave:
My name is Guido Woda, and I'm from Buenos Aires, Argentina. I'm a Uni dropout of Sound Engineering and Software Engineering, but have been working in software since 2006 nevertheless.
I've always had a particular interest in software design and architecture and I've focused my career mostly on web-based enterprise products. But in the last few years I've struggled to find meaning in being a cog in the machine, so I started to feel disconnected from the craft and eventually burned out and took a necessary time off. Last year (2024) I got back into the industry, but during my time off I found that I enjoyed working on creative collaborative projects, and I didn't want to lose this. So a few months ago I started looking for content creators that could get me to reconnect to the craft, and that's how I found the podcast and this community! :blush:

I'm really enjoying everything I read here and listen on the podcast. I don't know how yet, but I'd love to be able to contribute someday :heart_hands:

# Jeff Lindsay 2025-01-16 10:47 #
Hey everyone! I'm Jeff. Thought I'd try a new online community and this seemed like a good one. Like a lot of you, I assume, I think about this topic a lot. Maybe too much. Some notable background: back in the day I coined and popularized webhooks to try and make the web more programmable. I created a bunch of stuff to encourage and support adoption including a free tool called localtunnel that a friend turned into a company called Ngrok, if anybody's used that. Later I helped prototype Docker and built a bunch of Docker stuff in the early days. Like a tiny PaaS called Dokku. I kind of just like building what I think needs to exist and then quickly moving on.

Anyway, I'm in the Berkeley area if anybody wants to meet up or if there's an existing FoC in-person thing around here. I've kind of really been into the old Bell Labs projects Plan 9 and Inferno lately. If there's any Plan 9 curious people, we're hosting an online hangout / watch party for Plan 9 stuff in my quiet little Discord tomorrow night. Let me know if anybody wants an invite.

Otherwise, here for the vibes and to hopefully meet some cool people if I can remember how. :v:

Hi everyone, I’m Karl. I got into programming in the first place playing visual programming-esque games like LittleBigPlanet as a kid. I love playful and creative interactions for storytelling, teaching, etc.

For more context in the present, I’m a recent Ph.D. graduate from New York University, and I focused on human-computer interaction exploring how we could combine natural creativity, communication, and programming into an interactive communication medium of its own, in a sense. # Federico Pereiro 2025-01-08 13:55 #
Hi all! I'm Federico. Originally from Argentina, based in the Netherlands. I've been programming for about 15 years now (yikes!). For almost as long I have dreamed of build a programming tool to replace spreadsheets. The reason for this is that very early on I found Paul Graham's essays and Steve Yegge's rants, and those two set me in a contrarian path of looking for a better way to program. I love programming, but I am very aware of how much crap one has to deal with in order to get something done. I firmly believe (and already start to see) that that no longer needs to be the case, and I'm happy to interact with a community that feels in the same way.

Except for some sparse 1:1 communication with a few people in the open source community, I've been thinking and writing mostly in isolation. I'm now ready to change that and this feels like a great place to open up and start interacting more. I discovered FoC through val.town's blog.

Really looking forward to read your ideas and get some feedback on my work!

# Márton Gunyhó 2025-01-06 05:39 #
Hi all! I'm Márton, but I usually go by the nickname Marci. I'm in Finland, currently finishing up my PhD related to superconducting quantum computing.

I learned to program fairly late, only during my physics studies in uni. Turns out that I love it, and I'm sure I could have learned it much earlier if it wasn't so hard to get started. So the FoC goal of making programming more accessible strongly resonates with me.

I like to learn new programming languages, I've done Advent of Code with Racket, BQN (a modern variant of APL) and most recently with Pharo Smalltalk (it was great!). Another FoC-adjacent thing I like to do is making experimental-ish electronic music - I've dabbled in PureData and Supercollider, and also played around quite a bit with VCV Rack. I also sometimes like to do graphics programming (Processing and some GLSL), and I've been involved in the demoscene in Helsinki a little bit. And I of course love video games, I would like to find enough time some day to make my own.

I think I was primed for FoC ideas by noticing the awful state of most of the software I see around me, especially during my PhD studies working with lab control electronics and doing science in general. At some point I came across Bret Victor's talks on HN, and I was immediately hooked. After that I've been continuously absorbing related material like Ink & Switch, the local-first movement etc. After a while, I came across the podcast, and I was struck by how great it is. It has so many things I like - the interesting topics, fun banter, and the weird musical interludes and the overall off-beat format. I love it.

I'm excited to see what's going on in this forum!
# Matt Rasmussen 2025-01-05 06:59 #
Hi everyone, I'm Matt (https://x.com/mattrasmus). I got into future of coding/thinking topics originally when I wrote my own note-taking app called KeepNote (https://keepnote.org/, unmaintained) during grad school. The experience made me appreciate how powerful it can be to refer back to previous ideas and make new connections in my research (computational biology at the time). I am now interested in how note-taking can be viewed as a form of personal Data Engineering. That is, you could imagine an individual benefiting from similar activities that you find at a company-wide level: data capture into an unorganized data lake, ETLs that transform data into analysis friendly forms, personal dashboards and alerts of things that are important to you, etc.

More recently in my day job, I developed a flexible workflow engine redun (https://github.com/insitro/redun), mainly for scientific compute. However, the project has made me think again about the opportunities of blending workflow engines with personal note databases. The development of LLMs acting as assistants to help autogenerate code or call tools also seems like a chance to lower the bar for automatic compute over ones thoughts captured in their notes. I'm not entirely sure yet how it all fits together yet, but I've been trying prototypes and reading up on other people's explorations of these ideas.

I have followed the podcast and Ink and Switch work for years for inspiration on these topics. Looking forward to meeting you all and discussing more.
# Andy Yilin Tang 2024-12-26 11:44 #
Hi all! I'm Andy, a student currently studying robot learning and AI for real-world/verifiable tasks. I've previously crossed paths with several (generally more experienced / into HCI) folks in circles like these, and given my interest in these subjects I thought I'd join and hopefully meet some cool people! In terms of experience, I've been coding all my life, previously interned at Replit---which really changes your perspective on the conventional idea of who is a coder---and generally spawn side projects fast enough that they get shoved in a document so I don't try to act on all of them at once and leave them all half-finished.

Topics of interest include voice and physical interaction modalities, computer history (fun fact: according to Friendly Orange Glow my high school was a significant source of programmers for the PLATO system), and generative software ideas. Excited to meet you all!
# Roma Komarov 2024-12-25 11:08 #
Hey hey! I'm Roma. I am based around Paris, France. I love CSS, and everything I do is related to it in one way or another.

I work as a frontend engineer, working on design systems as my main job, and spending my spare time experimenting with CSS and trying to push the boundaries of what is possible with it. And then publishing long and nerdy articles on my personal site with the results. I'm also a CSSWG member. You are welcome to ask me any questions about CSS (on any level — it is important to understand what people struggle with for “simple” stuff as well).

I don't remember how exactly I stumbled upon the Future of Coding podcast: likely, from Mastodon, or from me searching for people talking about some of the Bret Victor's ideas. In many ways, I feel a bit out of my depth (being mostly a self-taught engineer), but I constantly try to get inspiration from very different areas.

In the new year, I am planning to work a bit more on one of my slowly ongoing pet projects (for live CSS explorations and permutations), and might share some progress here if I'll manage to fight my anxiety :slightly_smiling_face:

Hello all. I’m Chad, an old saxophonist turned programmer turned (after 30 years) VC with BlueYard Capital. I spent many years in the early Ruby community. Wrote some books, organized a bunch of conferences, helped write Ruby’s package manager, managed a bunch of people, etc. I’m a fan of the local first software movement (I met @Maggie Appleton at the first local first conference in Berlin earlier this year). I love things like esoteric programming languages and other fun wastes of time. My colleague Ben Scofield and I organized a conference in Iceland in 2018 called The Future of Software Development, which makes it surprising to me that I’m only now joining this community. I am professionally based in New York (as both a tech person and a jazz musician) but I travel constantly and hope to make it to a London meetup one of these days. Currently in flight on the way home from London as it happens. Though I’m a VC I still write code almost daily. I also have some pet ideas for generative software development that might be both interesting and controversial. Currently spending what free time I have learning about mechanism design and game theory.

# Luke Stanley 2024-11-01 17:16 #
:earth_africa: Hi all, I'm Luke Stanley. :keyboard: I started coding when I was 12 on a BBC Micro. I wanted to play games, but the disk drive didn't work, so I learned BASIC. :computer:When I got an IBM PC, I was fascinated by Visual Basic's RAD tools. I explored the Win32 API, ActiveX, OLE (interesting component systems), multimedia, and networking—teaching myself as much as I could.

:cd: There's a big gap between the rich multimedia learning tools I explored as a child—like Encarta, Ancient Lands, and The Way Things Work CD-ROMs—and how we can explore our personal, internal worlds with computers.
:art: It inspires me to explore visual language, hypertext, information retrieval, generative technology, semantic desktops, and self-assembling knowledge graphs to bridge that gap—something I'm still working on.

:robot_face: At 16, I got into what we'd now call machine learning. Inspired by Paul Graham's "A Plan For Spam" and my curiosity about Myers-Briggs categories, I created a dataset to predict introversion vs. extroversion from text samples using POPFile (a Bayesian spam filter) repurposed for a personality classification task called "Mindprise."

Around this time, I first interacted with futurists and AI safety figures like Eliezer Yudkowsky via IRC chat. I became an early supporter of the Singularity Institute (now MIRI) and learned about them through a memetics group on the same IRC server.

:lion_face::handshake: I met Lion Kimbro through an online BBC Magazine article, and we became friends. Lion got me into Carl Sagan, The Great Story, and making visual language lifemaps.

Around 2008, after Lion showed me his lifemap, I started the ThoughtTrail project, a metadata knowledge graph plugin system powering a contextual search tool that identified conversation topics in MSN Messenger and Skype chats.

It displayed Google Images and YouTube videos in a sidebar, with Wikipedia information accessible via a Python plugin. Worried about privacy issues, I pivoted to exploring a Visual Language Wiki (Cavepaint). I’m still interested in semi-automatic timelines and knowledge outline generation.

:footprints: I'm really intrigued by @Maggie Appleton's "Barefoot Developers" concept, I want to see spreadsheets, databases, and apps accessible and interoperable for non-developers.
I want my 70-year-old mum, who isn't technical, to create tools for the cat charity she supports. Helping people move beyond basic tables to databases and apps they can share, understand, and control is important and will unlock a lot. I agree with Alan Kay: the information revolution has barely started.

:mag_right: I built a search tool for my ChatGPT conversation dump containing over 4000 conversations.

:world_map: @Amelia Wattenberger's visual representations showing the same data as lists, tables, grids, maps, I think with D3 and embeddings.

:thinking_face: I'm curious about personal AI assistants for meaning prediction and emotional insight—what I think is important and why.

:male-technologist: Daniel Harris introduced me to the Future of Coding group, who I think was introduced by Steve Ruiz of Tldraw. More recently, I connected with @Kartik Agaram via Lion’s Internet Office on Discord.

:pleading_face: We should map out probable suffering and its remediation, improve our collective intelligence, and be mindful of the Fermi Paradox—treading carefully towards Pandora's box.

Some interests include:

:blue_book: Restricted vocabulary explanations like Thing Explainer by XKCD
:link: Improving representation and connectivity in embedding spaces
:robot_face: Fine-tuning small models for explanations, and on my ChatGPT dump to predict what I might say!
:cyclone: Exploring deep state-space models, training continuation, small models, and constraint solvers
:inbox_tray: Addressing information overload with unified systems
:world_map: Automatically creating visual maps, emoji topic outlines, ontologies, and hierarchical knowledge graphs. I made a Paul Graham essay map using embeddings
:orange_heart: We Feel Fine by Jonathan Harris
:globe_with_meridians: Map-making to connect personal understanding with broader knowledge, and developing semi-automatic timelines
:boom: I'm curious what high-impact solutions there are for big problems, and just having fun playing and exploring.
# Conrad Godfrey 2024-10-31 08:21 #
Hello!

I'm Conrad from London. I started writing code in Macromedia Flash 8 in like 2006 because I wanted to make cool shapes, and make my animations do things that weren't possible by hand.
I wound up studying computer sciecne and working in various startups in London - at the moment I'm doing a bit of Freelance Software Engineering and Teaching code too! I'd really like to do more teaching.

I'm only just discovering the Future of Code ecosystem - spiritually it reminds me of why I started coding. So I'm grateful it exists! Heard of it through a friend called Greg who pointed me in the direction of Todepond.

Currently trying to do more Digital Gardening, whatever takes my fancy at any given time, putting out lots of half finished stuff. What the kids are calling scrappy fiddles perhaps.

Interested in Maps, Music (broadly, but also the particularly niche of barbershop quartet singing), Visualisations, Multi-modal interfaces.

conradgodfrey.com

# Sam Gentle 2024-10-30 00:16 #
Hi, friends!

I'm a former software developer turned computational artist, previously from Sydney and now in LA. Finally getting on here after meeting some lovely people at the Ink & Switch unconf.

Programming has been a part of me for basically my entire life, but what it means to me has changed a lot over time. From "it's for fun and curiosity" to "it's for making stuff" to "it's for beautiful and powerful feats of engineering" to "it's for making beautiful things whether or not they're useful" to "oh that's art actually", which will hopefully someday lead me back to "it's for fun and curiosity" again.

I've felt spiritually connected to the FoC-verse for a long time, which (like most people here I'm assuming) began because almost every moment I spend interacting with a computer I'm trying not to breathe in all the wasted potential. That said, these days my interest is more in the potential of computation as an artistic medium, so I'm looking at creative and alternative models of computation more through the lens of "what's beautiful and meaningful?" than "what's more useful and less maddening?"

I used to post lil screen recordings of things I made on Twitter (@sgentle), these days I'm mostly on Instagram (@_sgentle) and trying to get started on Mastodon (@sgentle@mastodon.social). I have a whole lot of half-finished unreleased stuff from my making-art-but-don't-know-it transitional period that I'm still figuring out what to do with, but sometime soon hopefully I should start putting them somewhere. Meanwhile, here are a few actually released things: Flourish, Automata by Example, Markov Contact.

I spent a while being kinda isolated and it didn't work so well, so now I'm trying the other one. Definitely reach out if anything I've said seems interesting, you're into art/tech type things, or you just feel inexplicably drawn to weird and beautiful forms of computation :)
6 comments
# Medet Ahmetson 2024-10-12 01:55 #
Hello, everybody.
My name is Medet Ahmetson and I am launching a new social network where people create a community to work on the project together. The long term vision of the social network is a program synthesis, when a computer can fulfil the user's intention. But counter intuitively as most people try to solve it by improving AI, innovating on end user programming, I decided its better to make a place on internet when a non-technical people and programmers collaborate together.

Innovating the way how we use computers, decentralization is one of the dreams that I had since my teenage years. I formed it from old and mostly classic books in Computer Science. I am from Turkmenistan, a landlocked country in the Central Asia. In technology wise Turkmenistan stays behind than most of the countries. As such in late 2000s the Internet was quite expensive. Therefore, I could learn programming, understand how computers work only through a tiny budget, that allowed me to have a 5/25 megabytes per week limit. This allowed me to download, books the smallest in the size, dense in the coverage. As such those books were from the 80s, 70s. Rarely was something that was from late 2000s.

Despite learning the new technology, not different than todays tech stack, I was trained and got the knowledge from the pre-Linux/pre-Windows, immersed in the golden era of the hackers, stories of OS wars, how programming languages evolved. And telnet jokes.

On my free time, all these years I tried to achieve the program synthesis through various spectrums, following OS tutorials to create my own. Or writing my own programming languages from scratch. And also going into different programming language techniques such as Logic, Symbolic programming.

Here, I would like to find a like minded people who would be with me in a team to work on the social network. Or I hope I can get a support here. And that you guys will build your innovative stuff on the social network too.
# Thomas van Binsbergen 2024-10-06 00:45 #
Hi all.
My name is Thomas van Binsbergen and I am an assistant professor at the University of Amsterdam. I teach programming languages, programming concepts, compilers and software evolution. My research is on software language design, domain-specific languages (DSLs), and programming environments. Java and Haskell are my native languages, and I very much used to be a back-end code kinda guy. Nowadays I hardly code anymore, except for the occasional interpreter, and spend my time engrossed in mathematical abstractions and inference rules (the word @Ivan Reese was looking for in one of the podcasts), e.g., writing formal operational semantics, and writing research papers (as evidenced by the use of "e.g.,").

My interest in FoC is primarily because of my work on novel programming environments, legal DSLs, and rule-based, high-level, declarative languages. I found FoC through the Podcast on Laurence Diver's Rule(s) of Code paper which struck a chord with me (both the paper and the podcast) because of the forward, out-of-the-box thinking that characterises FoC. In the past few years my students and I spent effort on the eFLINT DSL, a language for formalising interpretations of laws and applying them in different contexts (case-based reasoning, access control, verification). Another research line is on "exploratory programming" in which programmers (but we target domain-experts such as data scientists, not necessarily software engineers) can experiment with alternative execution paths and compare outputs and effects. Most of my work is published at SPLASH and I will be attending again this year; so perhaps we will run into each other there.

The primary reasons for me to join are to get further inspired by the interesting discussions and demonstrations that are shared here and to find potential collaborators from industry or academia in joint (interdisciplinary) projects. I mention interdisciplinary here because, as a back-end kinda guy engrossed in abstractions, I certainly need help from people that can provide creative insights related to visual design and interfaces!

Looking forward to meeting you all!
5 comments
# Daniel Harris 2024-09-30 05:53 #
Hello everyone! My name is Daniel and my handle everywhere is dahacouk. I found the FoC whilst also finding the Local-First community and attending the meeting in Berlin this year. I think the main thing that drives me is the need to be in control of my environment, be that physical or digital. Not the easiest theme to pick for one's life's work, but hey!

I don't code anymore, but I do long to build little useful collaborative apps without coding. It all started way back with a ZX81... Spectrum... Amiga... PC... Mac. I studied art in the late 80s. Ran an ISP in the mid 90s. Dreamed and talked of having interoperability and open protocols ubiquitous in every sector through the 00s, and started a nonprofit open source research project. Started building demonstrations in the early 10s with EU research funding. Arrived in the 20s with a team and the beginnings of an app to build mini apps: like if Excel could build apps and not just spreadsheets, and we could email them to each other. My projects are on my LinkedIn as I don't want to break the rules! :wink: So, now I'm immersed in: no-code, local-first and malleable-software isms. I've shared our work in #share-your-work

What I'm most interested in is how end-users can build and alter simple apps. Rather than building a typical fine-grained programming environment, I'm wondering about what people do most when interacting with services and data in their daily lives: create and modify things, manage relationships between things. List, filter, analyse and select/group things. What minimal set of user-interface and compute blocks could be configured and combined to provide a viable environment for people to manage their digital lives?

So, yes, I'm excited about never having to go to a website or app (where my data is currently siloed) ever again. For instance, I'd like to have a consistent shopping interface that I can configure and tailor to my needs through which I can access all shops: a personal Amazon if you will. So, I guess that means services become headless? Luckily the ubiquity of APIs makes this dream more viable. The trick is to make it understandable and attractive – and I'm beginning to think that this is the 'not the easy part'! :wink: Look forward to hanging out in FoC and sharing our experiments. Cheers!
2 comments
# Tomas Petricek 2024-09-25 14:57 #
Hi everyone!

I'm Tomas - I have been lurking here for some time, but I thought it may be time to join properly. I've been involved in various things around programming languages (functional programming in F#, type systems for tracking context information, type providers and tools for data science) - but recently my interest has been stateful and interactive "programming systems" (as opposed to "programming languages"). With @Joel Jakubovic and @Jonathan Edwards, we wrote Technical dimensions of programming systems. I've also been trying to make sense of some interesting past programming systems like BASIC and I post various other things at https://tomasp.net/

After happy 10 years in the UK, I moved back to Prague and I'm now an assistant professor at Charles University (and we have some funding for post-docs and PhD students interested in those topics!) I will also be organising the <Programming> 2025 conference in Prague in June next year! https://2025.programming-conference.org/
6 comments
# Josh Sunshine 2024-09-20 13:50 #
Hi everyone! I'm Josh Sunshine, an Assistant Professor at Carnegie Mellon University. I lead the Penrose team. Penrose is a platform for conceptual diagramming. In Penrose, you declare what you want to be true of your diagram and Penrose automatically lays out your diagram to meet your goals. Under the hood, we use some interesting differentiable geometry, numeric optimization, and compiler tricks to make it work.
I'm broadly interested in research at the intersection of human-computer interaction (HCI) and programming languages (PL). That intersection seems closely connected to this group. I also run an annual research workshop called PLATEAU that focuses on PL+HCI which may interest some of you.
11 comments
# Pavel Mikhailovskii 2024-09-03 11:54 #
Hi everyone!
I'm leading a research project at JetBrains that aims to reimagine software development and explore such ideas as minimalist programming language design, unification of different programming paradigms, and novel ways of working with code. It's called Ludwig after Ludwig Wittgenstein.
3 comments

# Saketh Kasibatla 2024-08-15 15:25 #

# Guyren Howe 2024-08-11 13:43 #
I wrote this for the new forum, but it won’t let me post, so I’ll put it here:

Guyren Howe

guyren@relevantlogic.com
frest.substack.com
@unclouded
lydb.xyz

My major thesis for the future of coding is that SQL is a gaping wound in the computer industry.

The relational model is a straightforward way to use declarative First Order Logic to retrieve and manipulate data. But SQL is a horrid way to achieve this.

Datalog (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Datalog#:~:text=Datalog%20is%2….), which is basically the pattern matching that all the languages are acquiring now, but for data, is the natural alternative.

In fact, most of most business software (heck, most of most software of any kind) can in fact be expressed through the relational model. The only parts of typical software that needs to be written in a Turing Complete language are:
• side-effecting things (e.g. sending email)
• efficiency-focused computation (e.g. signal processing)
• some types of complex sequential logic (e.g. some aspects of UIs)
Everything else can and should be expressed in Datalog.

The advantage of so doing for developers would be software that is more robust, simple and flexible.

The advantage for non-developers is that e.g. FileMaker demonstrates that non-developers find manipulating relations natural, so this is also a way to let non-programmers do computing more easily.

I’ve developed some theory around what software like that would look like. I discuss this at frest.substack.com. Maybe start with https://frest.substack.com/p/what-is-frest
5 comments
# Oliver Medhurst 2024-08-01 06:10 #
Hello! I'm Oliver (or @canadahonk in some places). as of late I have been writing/messing with compilers "written for the future" (like compiling JS to Wasm). happy to chat about ~anything :slightly_smiling_face:
6 comments
# John Christensen 2024-07-31 06:34 #
Hello! I've spent the last year of my life going through the Bret Victor -> Anarchist pipeline (no idea if this pipeline is unique to me or not).

I started programming doing undergraduate physics research in materials simulation. I really enjoyed it and loved making 3Blue1Brown-esque animations to visualize research concepts that were tricky to fit in my head or on a whiteboard.

After finishing my undergraduate physics program I got a job as a software developer for a big tech medical software company. I was optimistic that I could write code that would help people, but I spent 4 years working on projects that ranged from being potentially marginally helpful to a handful of healthcare IT workers, to projects primarily designed (IMO) to extract more money out of patients. Pushing back on these projects turned out to be too hard from me, and eventually decided the nice paycheck was not not worth the sisyphean task of trying to work against the financial interests of the US healthcare system.

Looking for "alternative" approaches to programming, where motivations are centered around positive human values, I first came across Bret Victor's work. From there I found things like the FoC podcast, the Recurse Center, a gold mine of recorded Strange Loop talks, and lovely folks on Mastodon (me: Johnwithanh@hachyderm.io). It was amazing to suddenly find so many new programming concepts that look more like fundamental truths, and less like arbitrary design choices. Lots of people have put a lot of thought into how design programming languages/tools for humans, and carefully consider the effects they have on other humans. Why didn't anyone tell me sooner?! (obvious now, but I didn't know what functional programming was despite being a "professional" developer and completing a CS minor)

I decided to quit my job without something else lined up (super privileged that this was an option), and spent a few months at the Recurse Center. Having the chance to build and learn whatever interested me and doing it with other people doing the same was wonderfully liberating! It reassured to me that programming could still be an edifying practice for me, despite its adjacency to some negative dominating forces of our current world.

After Recurse I found a physics professor at a near by university looking for a research software engineer to build a visual programming system for researchers to prototype new MRI signal processing techniques. I honestly couldn't believe my luck! I started few months ago and have been building a simple node and wire system on top of tldraw for the UI. I'm excited to continue to learn from previous work in this area, and figure out an approach that works well for my problem domain.

Learning a host of new paradigms has had a huge impact on how I write code, but what I appreciate most about these new paradigms and the communities adjacent to them, is the affect it has had on my worldview. I feel much more confident now than I did a year ago that the good and bad of our world today was never an inevitable conclusion, and that most obvious future is likewise undetermined. I'm hopeful that I can find sustainable ways to push for a more humane future of computation with people in communities like this one!
7 comments
# Polly 2024-07-05 11:01 #
Hi I'm Polly. I care about security and other things. I've done a lot of hacking the past 5 years, a lot of cryptography but also webs security, binary exploitation and whatnot. Almost all of it was in the context of CTFs. Back when I was a kid I learnt programming through creative coding, where I wrote a lot of games and simulations and nonsense programs. I have a website with very little on it.

Lately I've been very interested in thinking about building secure software. It's kinda the problem that my field is unable to solve, or even really think about. I really like Rust because it made a good push towards that.
I got very sucked into a bunch of the blog posts on todepond.com after re-discovering Lu's mastodon, and have since binged some of the future of coding stuff and read/watched so many of the cited works.

# Piotr Walas 2024-06-29 04:56 #
Heya all,

Just found this community through weird youtube->todepond->twitter->ink&switch swirl of events. I am Piotr generally electronic/software engineer (I guess this would be computer engineer) extremely interested in building experimental software and tools. I spend a lot of my time delving into Artificial Life and Artificial Intelligence topics, which you can see on my github: https://github.com/PeterWaIIace

However, I came here to share my largest project so far called EyeGestures. It is python (for now) library enabling engineers to build gaze-driven interfaces just by using built-in webcam (so you can make your own gaze tracker or eye tracker in seconds now - no need for expensive hardware nor license!). No servers required, everything runs locally: https://github.com/NativeSensors/EyeGestures

Hope you will enjoy, and look forward to chat with you all!

I am very excited to explore what people are up to here and (crap I hit enter again pfffaaaaaeifuveurv) learning together!

# Jim Kring 2024-06-25 21:24 #
Hi :wave: I’m Jim Kring. I co-authored LabVIEW for Everyone (back when people read books) and I’m working to self-host a visual programming language. I’ve been using LabVIEW for nearly 30 years, and a few years back I started exploring re-writing LabVIEW in LabVIEW. I’ve got a lot of interesting ideas in this space (many of them working) and am now starting to implement them in modern web technologies and with AI co-pilot capabilities. I’m also very interested in visual languages as a means for more efficiently interacting with AI (and parallel compute targets) as a means for having visibility into proposed actions by AI agents and enable human accountability for such systems to keep them safe. I’m looking forward to sharing ideas and successes. Kind Regards, Jim

# agnes cameron 2024-06-10 04:10 #
hello, i’m agnes — I work as a technician and a lecturer at university of the arts london’s creative computing institute, and also work on games/writing/art-related things.

I spend a lot of time thinking about how people develop a sense of agency in relation to technology. I recently came across the tadi web ‘slippy mindset’ page + thought it was a great articulation of something I often try to get across in my teaching and technical work — that there’s always more than one way to do something.

I’m also really interested in collective knowledge structures and tools for describing/realising them — I’ve run a reading group for a few years now called the Knowledge Arrangement Reading Group (it’s an open group if anyone here wants to join) + am also an enthusiastic (if intermittent) wikipedia editor.

right now, I’m doing a technical writing fellowship with Bellingcat around diverse satellite imaging indices, thinking a lot about ‘meta-methods’ for thinking about imaging as a physical process. I’m also just starting a research project around developing knitting software, and also learning to make DIY synths (in the autumn I’m going to run a ‘circuit diagram reading group’ at the CCI where we make synthesisers together from scratch).

I think it’s really cool that this space exists! If anyone is based in london and wants to come visit the CCI / hang out and talk about coding things lmk :slightly_smiling_face:

# Jase Pellerin 2024-05-25 22:57 #
Hard to follow after Karl's lovely intro above, but I'll try! :see_no_evil:

I'm Jase, a big nerd and product / software person. I'm an aspiring poet, blogger, entrepreneur and many other things that are still stretching their legs to hopefully one day make it off the ground.

I learned to code by customizing Myspace layouts for my junior high friends and their (very cool) bands. I failed out of Computer Engineering in college, did a bunch of soul searching, and eventually got my degree in Accounting to save face. I worked as an accountant for 3 whole months before selling everything I owned and buying a one-way ticket to the Pacific Northwest to hitchhike and couch-surf my way to a more fitting future.


My current career passion is making small processes that help focus a team's energy toward an actual problem that real people care about. This is a hurricane of pain and frustration, but when it works, it's so incredibly satisfying that I can't help but throw myself back in.

I care deeply about people on an individual level. I want to help shape a future that focuses on human-scale problems with human-scale solutions. I believe scale kills good products.

I'm currently developing an app that tells local stories anywhere in the US, with my business partner and very good friend. More importantly, we're building a collection of systems that help us make things and get feedback from real people. My ultimate goal is to use these systems to solve many small problems in unlame ways. I hope to start writing about these systems in the near future.


I'm looking forward to exploring this space, and I'd love to have a 1-1 chat with any of you about anything at all. Please don't hesitate to reach out, I'd love to hear from you :v::skin-tone-2:

# Karl Svartholm 2024-05-20 07:31 #
Hello Everybody!

So this is me:
1984 :star: Born. [include events before this?]
1995 :technologist: BASIC & HTML.
2000 :hankey: Server-side web (& city life).
2006-2011 :briefcase: Coder employee + Agile & alcohol.
2011 :cat2: Left to freelance & build iPad Twister for kittens etc.
2012 :dizzy_face: Lost my way.
2013 :rainbow: Looked in India, Nepal & Berlin.
2014 :mortar_board: "Never again software!" tried misc., including ~homelessness.
2014 :chains: Software consulting.
2016-2021 :money_with_wings: Startups & drukqs.
2020 :tired_face: Burnout & :deciduous_tree: countryside (again).
2023 :globe_with_meridians: Joined K-Web (as curator), next trying to revive the vision...
2023 :heart: My daughter baby Scout!!
2024 :mouse2: K-Web → Engelbart et al etc... (& void systems see below).

...and that (researching Engelbart for James Burke's Knowledge Web) is how I found this slack!

A few books, videos etc that affected my worldview:

~2005 :film_projector: James Burke's docu series...
~2008 :books: Read Don't Make Me Think → usability/UX fundamentalist.
~2010 :performing_arts: Hans Rosling (live).
~2012 :shinto_shrine: Bret Victor, Inventing on Principle.
~2014 :orangutan: Sapiens.
later :scroll: Big History (David Christian & friends) :boom: The Dawn of Everything
earlier :person_in_lotus_position: Mindfulness meditation...

Despite agile, startups & mental health issues, I'm doing okay. Sort of :zany_face:
BTW, I live close to Gothenburg, Sweden.

My ~2 FoC projects:

• :globe_with_meridians: The Knowledge Webs, an epic project / family of projects originally envisioned by James Burke in the 1990s. It is a bit like a visual immersive Wikipedia (focusing on the connections), originally with 4 or more "tools": timeline, globe/map network graphs & text + hypermedia. We currently suck at describing the visions, most recent attempt: GitHub ...this was a rather narrow vision from last year, outdated & since abandoned / superseded. Older but more comprehensive vision descriptions can be found on YouTube (the "prequel" documentary series Connections (1978) can also be found there or archive.org).
◦ Also exploring a Dynamicland inspired interface (including battery powered wireless standalone dials, sliders etc).
• :doughnut: Void Systems — Web apps (/ PWAs + electron logger/launcher) rebuilding & reclaiming my own computing experience 2 min at a time from within itself (mobile usually)... think I'll have to explain / show this stuff another time... feel like this introduction has all been a little bit too much & too rambling already.
I'm sorry for this entrance.
Anyways, looking forward to know & explore with (some of) you! :smiley:

# John Choi 2024-05-17 20:59 #
Hi all!

I'm John, a backend software engineer in Seoul, specializing in AI with a personal interest in visualization and media-related programming.

I discovered this community by chance. While organizing my podcast subscriptions. I noticed episodes from FoC featuring Bret Victor and Miller Puckette, and had to listen! In addition to the subject matter, the style of discussion—tendency toward metaphors, mapping out conceptual spaces by considering their logical extremes, attention to useful details for generalization/abstraction—really resonated with me. When I found there was an entire community dedicated to this spirit, I had to join and say hi.

Currently, I'm particularly interested in flowcharts and diagrams-as-code. I'm working on a toy project called mermazing, which aims to add interactivity to mermaid.js graphs. To start with, I've added a feature where hovering over a node in the graph highlights all upstream and downstream nodes. This proved immensely useful for me personally when navigating complex mermaid graphs.
(Small tip: if you work in mermaid.live, add z to the URL hostname (making it mermaidz.live) and you can see my project's version of your mermaid graph!)

I'm excited to be here and look forward to exchanging resources and insights with everyone. :slightly_smiling_face:

---

tl;dr
• Name & Profession & Location
◦ John, backend software engineer, Seoul
• Discovery
◦ Found community via FoC podcast episodes (Bret Victor, Miller Puckette)
• Current Interests
◦ flowcharts, diagrams-as-code
• Projects
◦ mermazing — adding interactivity to mermaid.js graphs
▪︎ highlights upstream and downstream nodes on hover

# Marcin S 2024-05-10 12:36 #
Hello, everybody. My name is Marcin and I am a hacker. I found this place after finding a HN thread about Bret Victor, made a bet it would be full of interesting people, and I have won that bet.

I've read some of the introductions here and I wonder where all these people were during my life at academia. I quit my degree - for good reasons - but I do miss having a network to jump into projects with.

I've worked on a lot of smaller projects in different environments- everything between application reverse engineering Android to assisting researchers with biological modelling. An early-learned habit of extreme privacy means I have little to share, unfortunately.

I've joined this place to see if I can learn how to think out of the box more often; what things combine together to make an effective engineer in unexpected ways. I also have a desire to do new things, and I can only hope this place has plenty of unlaid roads to fill.

Finally - if there's anybody within Morocco that wants to meet up, let me know. It just so happens to be where I'm living in the foreseeable future.
# Geert Roumen 2024-05-09 11:44 #
Hey everyone,

I’m Geert, an Interaction Designer, who is very interested in the future of programming/coding beyond current paradigms. For my master thesis I worked with Arduino on making a future way of coding using active learning and acting out scenarios as a starting point; Arduino Action (https://geertroumen.nl/portfolio/index.php?page=action ). For this thesis I did a variety of Bret Victorian prototypes and explorations to see where this could lead me. I have been working at Microsoft Research on the inclusive design for the future of work, with the team who created Project Torino (https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/project/project-torino/) focussing on tools to help visually impaired children to be more socially aware (https://geertroumen.nl/portfolio/index.php?page=microsoft). Before that I’ve been doing an internship at LEGO working on the current generation Mindstorms products. Currently I’m working on experience prototyping for products within Accenture Industrial Design.

Besides that I have been teaching teachers Arduino since begin of high school and are very interested in how we can expand the field of programming beyond the textual representations. Given that Excel might be the biggest programming environment created, us technologist might need to rethink what we see as programming.

I’m very looking forward to have some conversations with people within this community on how to move forward, what it would take and what we think is forward to start with. I’m passionate about the view of Bret Victor, but see more problems with technology that his principle, and more problems with this world than that only can be solved with technology. (In my thesis on Arduino Action the lack of togetherness and transparency with the current tools seemed more pressing than direct manipulation for example).

Feel free to write me a message if any of this resonates with you, or if you want to talk about anything. I would love to have some chats, but also preferably in person meeting where we can turn the world around in our imaginations; I’m living in Eindhoven, the Netherlands. So anywhere in the Netherlands is easy, outside might be online first.

# John Chang 2024-04-29 12:33 #
Hello from Stockholm, Sweden (although I'm originally American). I'm a software engineer / startup founder and I've worked in both big tech and startups/scale-ups, most recently in IoT and cloud backend, but want to get back to sort of my "roots": as a kid, I read about Englebart/Kay/Macintosh team and I fell in love with the vision of personal computing and the belief in the potential of software as a new medium for human thought and expression. I was one of the first members of Brad Myers' Natural Programming project at CMU HCII as an undergrad, and I worked at Apple as an engineer on the Mac OS X user experience team during the wondrous Steve Jobs era (I worked on every release from Public Beta to 10.6 Snow Leopard).

I loved HyperCard back in the day and I'm interested in anything along that vein, i.e. end-user programming for the masses. I'm also interested in the problem of funding and commercializing work in this space of "future of coding". I want to see more innovation make its way to the real world, not just remain interesting research projects that languish. Currently I'm participating in a global startup incubator program (Antler.co) and open to starting something new.

# Marek Kalnik 2024-04-22 04:20 #
Hi :wave:

My name is Marek and I’m a CTO and co-founder of a software house BAM.tech.

I have been a web developer for few years and been a CTO for almost 10 years now. As my company sells mostly “developer time”, I have the feeling that my business model is reaching it’s end and I try to prepare my company for the transition.

Last year I created a “Feature of Software” team at our company that I manage directly and we work on creating tools and processes that leverage AI in all steps of software creation: product management, project management, design, coding. We are working mainly on:
• training people on existing tools (GPTs, Copilot and such)
• creating our own tools: custom GPTs to remplace / improve on different steps in the process, code generation tools
• spreading the word about AI and it’s impact
I live in Paris, happy to connect on line or in the physical world.
# Chris Midtempo 2024-04-16 03:19 #
So, a quick introduction.

My name’s Chris, a Kiwi living on the Norfolk coast (UK). I’m a web/systems architect who’s been building things online since ’98, mostly as a solo/self-contained do-everything - was LAMP, now working in Node/React/Next + a little Python/Tensorflow.

Two years ago, I jumped into corporate life for some stability/security, designing/building a chatbot management platform for a large financial company – structured conversations, rather than GenAi (firmly of the belief that LLMs are not – and may never be – capable of truth).

Outside of the paid stuff, I’m working on a music streaming system that dynamically selects songs by analysing and blending the key/intensity/harmonics when one track ends and the next begins. It’s a not-for-profit, zero user-tracking, not-looking-for-funding project. You can listen here.

Away from a screen, I keep bees and spend time in our pottery studio - where I’m still (and will forever be) learning to throw.
3 comments
# Ricardo Abreu 2024-04-12 12:52 #
Hey everyone! I’m a Software Engineer and the founder of a startup called Midicircuit - a music education app that helps you get started making music. I used to be a rapper, I make beats and play the bass guitar.

I am originally from Lisbon, Portugal :smile: but have been living in London for 10y now and working with all kinds of startups as a perm and eventually as a contractor while bootstrapping my own ideas.

So I am really curious but also I am here to learn something new, to meet awesome people, maybe grab a coffee with them, build cool things together, to be serendiputous.

Thank you and,

Slack ya later :v::skin-tone-5:

# Declan 2024-04-09 10:13 #
Hey, all! I'm Declan, I develop calculang, a language for calculations (calculang.dev @calculang on twitter/fosstodon). I've been lurking in the group for some weeks now and look forward to sharing a new gallery/playground and other bits about calculang soon and hearing your feedback!
calculang is about a bunch of things, but fundamentally about separating numbers from programming so they can be visualized, followed, communicated and things that are relatively hard when mixed with general programming.
By itself it fits in the FP space too: everything is a pure function, and "input inference" is intended to make the functions (or 'formulas') flexible by removing the tedious threading of arguments. This is the only really technical thing and it's <100 LOC and something I found really interesting to play with.
Since I only care about pure numbers calculang should integrate with other programming languages to 'do things': mainly Javascript now (calculang transpiles into JS). + I'm beginning to do some things with Python maybe Julia.
My examples focus a lot on visualization and interactivity with numbers/their models, which JS is well primed for, but needs to generalize better also like spreadsheets do.
I look forward to sharing progress and to learning from the community! :grinning:
# Marek Rogalski 2024-04-04 04:19 #
Hello all computing futurists! I'm a fellow future of coding enthusiast. I believe that with some effort computing could be made more ergonomic, more egalitarian and more efficient. I particularly like in-person meetings, quiet natural environments and morning hours (anyone up for a dog walk in the Łódź area?) but I'm also fine with commuting to an evening pub meeting in Berlin or London if that's where other FoC enthusiasts hang out.
