# Aman Jha 2021-11-14 16:14 #
Hey everyone! I'm working on a new vision for the terminal - one that uses plain english.

To that end, I've been building Rosie for the past few weeks, and a friend mentioned I come here. It's still really new, but it's a step forward. If you've ever spent 15 minutes crawling StackOverflow to figure out some specific CLI command, then Rosie is for you. Just type in plain english what you'd like to do, and Rosie will give you the CLI command.

More importantly, in the desktop app, Rosie will actually run the command. Coupled with a revamped file explorer (think Superhuman, but Finder), I think we can really change this archaic part of coding.

I hope you guys like it! Excited to be part of this community.
3 comments
# John Voorhees 2021-11-11 06:49 #
So excited to meet everyone here! I'm John, the founder and creator of the Primitive Immersive Development Environment. I started Primitive in 2015 because I wanted to create the IDE of the future. I believe the future of programming is collaborative, immersive, and powered by spatial computing and artificial intelligence.

The Primitive IDE is my life's work. It is a collaborative 3D/VR environment where users explore codebases to learn, review, and debug code in an unlimited environment. A few things that makes Primitive unique:
• Primitive crawls GitHub and has a fully explorable mapping of the top repositories
• Anybody can view their own code on their local machine and see a directory and file mapping in a 3D spatial layout
• Programming files are parsed by a variety of tools (ANTLR, Roslyn, Clang, JavaC) to show their AST structure and to enable animated reference maps in the 3D space
• For Java, Primitive can display multi-thread runtime traces and a memory graph in the 3D environment
• There is also a backend that integrates with Bitbucket, GitHub, and GitLab and automatically analyzes your private repos to share with your team. This is great for code walkthroughs and onboarding
• The backend does AST diffing in git, and will show you changes in the codebase as a 3D model. This is amazing for code review, because it's very easy to see what has changed in a PR
• Finally, and most experimentally, we have a voice-controlled Codex implementation. This is the future that I'm most excited about: a team of people asking a machine to generate code, that gets displayed and tested in a 3D VR environment. Here is a demo: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=icHLoxOFerk
I'm glad to have discussions about spatial computing and AI enabled programming. I just discovered this community and I'm excited to hear about what everyone is working on.

https://primitive.io/
https://twitter.com/PrimitiveVR
6 comments
# Owen Campbell-Moore 2021-11-02 12:03 #
Hello Friends! I am Owen, an ex-Google/ex-Facebook person working in SF on the future of coding.

My background / journey in this space:
• I worked on Google Chrome for 3 years, leading Progressive Web Apps and the future of x-platform development
• I concluded it was possible to build amazing web apps, but far far too hard
• I am disappointed nobody has solved “write once, run everywhere”, but where the output is UI native to the target SDK (and includes Web Support), and adapted to the OS / form factor of the device 
• I became very interested in React Native development and love following the advancements in the React space
My conclusions:
• I believe we need to start coding at a way higher level of abstraction, i.e. describing the features of our products at a semantic level rather than UI and in terms of complex low-level logic
• If we can increase the level of abstraction for coding for certain classes of apps I believe we can enable:
◦ “Write once run everywhere”, but where the high level descriptions of products can be compiled into super polished native UIs best suited to the form factor of the target device.
◦ Making it 1000X easier for people to build apps and web apps, since describing a feature semantically is far easier than at an implementation level
My vision for the future of coding consumer software:
• I want people to be able to re-build products like AirBnB by simply describing (in a formal Domain Specific Language, via a slick web GUI) the things users can do in the app, and then for the platform to compile this down to super polished UIs for every OS, plus auto generate a production backend.
I’m working on this space at a new company I recently founded in San Francisco called Sutro, here’s a post with a bit more detail, and I’d love to feedback or to chat with folk any time interested in this! https://www.notion.so/Intro-to-Sutro-raising-the-level-of-ab…
# Dalton Banks 2021-11-01 15:41 #
I don’t believe I’ve ever intro’d myself, so here goes! My winding path:
1. First love was reading & language - hundreds of books while homeschooling (up to 8th grade)
2. Puzzles were my jumping off point into math (which I’d hated). Joined the math team and got shown how to program a TI-83, got hooked on ‘game’ programming. The ease of getting pixels on the screen has haunted me ever since.
3. Undergrad at Penn in bioengineering: not the best choice of major (should have done CS/CompE), but developed appreciation for the resilience/scalability of biological systems compared to mechanized tech, as well as alt forms of computing (e.g. biomolecular logic gates)
4. A bioinspired robotics class followed by a WONDERFUL intro to mechatronics intro’d me to electronics & microcontrollers and connected a bunch of dots. The ability to turn ideas into real devices was heady.
5. Switched to masters in robotics and did a capstone project with very talented partner. Designed a system to connect assistive inputs for people with disabilities to game consoles motivated by observations growing up with my bro. Also led to a neat collab with a rehab robotics lab using gaming for stroke rehab. Decided it was worth trying to make exist in the world & entered the spooky realm of entrepreneurship.
6. Have pretty much nailed the liminal space between success & failure - much progress made, still no product. In the process, discovered Bret Victor, the FoC slack, Alan Kay, etc & have had my mind repeatedly blown while mining computing history. The more I’ve learned, the more I’ve come to see accessibility and FoC as twin issues best tackled as a pair. Finally had some breakthroughs based on an NSF Phase I SBIR grant, & am reformulating the system around proper computing atoms (h/t Alan Kay) vs a glorified config system. Feeling good about our odds if Phase II funding comes through.
My thoughts have crystallized quite a bit over the past few months, and I’m looking forward to good conversations here and progress to report. Feel free to reach out; I enjoy and benefit from verbal sculpting. An emerging primary viewpoint is programming as modeling & simulation (i.e. proper “science”).
4 comments
# Lukas Süss 2021-10-25 06:08 #
What brought me to the future of programming space ...

Hi, I am Lukas M Süss (aka mechadense)

I guess for me my path to "future of coding" relevant topics was initially kicked off many years ago (2005 maybe?) when stumbling across a german website with name "C-hater in 10 days".
Before I already had banged my head into the limitations of current day programing languages again and again.
• First in the context of game programming,
• and later in the context of 3D modelling.
That was revelation one.
Here the (german) page in the internetarchive:
https://web.archive.org/web/20080612103719/http://www.math.u… )

This eventually led me to taking a course about the haskell programming language and the theory behind it. What I learnd there was quite eye opening and my second revelation.
_The (german) course: http://www.complang.tuwien.ac.at/knoop/fp185A03_ws2122.html — by Jens Knoop — at TU Vienna_

At some point when I came across diagramming sofware (then I used yEd) I sketched out all of what I've learned so far. Thereby realizing …
• (A) … how far even Haskell is still improvable. — Revelation three.
• (B) … how much can be learned by high level diagramming and how awesome it would be if that would fall out of a programming language
I was starting to desire autopropagarion of renaiming, automatic code substitutions, and more … Desiring structured editing — basically.

My fourth revelation was making the connection between John Tromps Lambda diagrams and textual code, leading to my work on "Annotated Lambda Diagrams (ALDs)".
-- _http://apm.bplaced.net/w/index.php?title=Annotated_lambda_diagram_
I found that translating existing ideas into these diagrams greatly helps me in understanding them. Which makes me think that this may be a good "semitextual" programming interface.
Now I'm in the process of investigating ideas-and-work of some great people in the context of ALDs ( Looking at ideas from: Conal Elliott, Jonathan Edwards, Cryus Omar et.al. , Daniel P. Friedman, ... ) All this as spare time efforts.

My fifth and so far final revelation (during 2018) emergerd probably mostly from my frustration with nonexistence …
• … of local-first selfhosting options.
• … of personal local-first self-owned content curation assistents.
I realized that in order for good novel technical solutions of core problems to thrive sociotechnical problems need to be solved in unison (unison the word not unison the proglang here). Code just cannot be borderlessly shared if there are no well designed means that allow for judement of its trustworthyness.
What I want to see eventually are distributed ledgers that:
• do not insist on maximally global public consensus for everything and
• are nonmonetary at their core.
Very few projects aim for that. In fact I only know one so far.

— — —

Regarding the "future of coding" side of my interests I'm into:
• denotative core language design
• content adressed design (datastorage and versioning)
• dependent typing
• agent centric design (sociotechnical aspect)
• and what I missed here ...
My core interest though is actually advanced atomically precise manufacturing (APM). Aimed at future gemstome-metamaterial-on-chip-factories. But if software does not get fixed I see a dark future ahead. Both for the path there and the eventual result.
5 comments

# Kilian Butler 2021-10-15 05:46 #

• I am a frustrated computer user and dream of better things. This community newsletter has been a source of inspiration on that side for a while
• I wrote my first blog on why now is the time to pay attention to human-computer interaction recently. In short, all of the pieces for a new computing paradigm of the size of desktop -> mobile are now in place. Except whereas the shift to mobile made computing ubiquitous, I think the next shift will make computing 10x better

# Diego Moya 2021-09-30 15:03 #
Hi! I've been told about this community as a place where one can present some early stage ideas to like-minded people aware of the drastic changes that the landscape of programming systems is undergoing.

During my graduate studies I did research in the fields of both theoretical Constraint Programming and End User Development, although now I only do it as a personal side project.  I devoured the now classics "Watch what I do" and "Your wish is my command", as well as all the UX books I could find and anything design-related in a wide sense. I'm a believer that the Cognive Dimensions framework of TRG Green et. al. has potential for its intended use as a meta-language for exploring software design and pivoting it in unusual directions, though that may be over-confidence on my understanding of it. :slightly_smiling_face:

I certainly have ideas that I would like to develop into a coherent explanation, on how to create a system for information workers who want to build their own data processing workflows without constant assistance from software engineers. I've seen the venerable copy/paste being used for gluing disparate tools into personal workflows through lots of back-and-forth manual data transfers; I've even seen this copy/paste protocol upgraded from humble raw text to rich text, supporting style and multimedia objects. And I have insights for a new upgrade that provides the protocol with structured data and persistent semi-automated workflows, building the mythical "unix pipes for visual user interfaces" that we were promised decades ago.

I have seen many signs that the computing field is converging towards a form of computation with novel aspects reappearing in different contexts, where many of my ideas about modern computation appear incomplete in various systems, with no single one containing all of them. I would love to explore what expectations people have about modern knowledge-processing devices, and whether my insights could be used to support those expectations and improve their users work. I hope this community will help me grow in knoledge.
9 comments
# Sophie Smithburg 2021-09-23 09:36 #

• think full time employment isn't a safe or ethical engagement structure for most techies

• very open to talking about my work and sharing/learning from others

# Aqeel Hashim 2021-09-01 05:06 #
Hello I found this community through YouTube rabbit-holes and research dives across google which lead me to a talk on the dion systems by allen webster and ryan fluery because I am researching interesting and new ways of representing ideas and thoughts into code or anything machine readable.
I am very much interested in the ideas around language design and rethinking how software engineering is done. It seems as though people have forgotten that computers are simply tools that we manipulate to solve problems for us.

# Sam Butler 2021-08-07 07:57 #
Hey all, my name is Sam. Glad to join this community.

I freelance part-time, and spend most of my days working on what seems most important, for better future outcomes and better futures we'll all experience.

That often includes digital things, based on the collaborative potential that the Internet enables — as well as the risks / downsides / opportunity costs, of the attention economy and big tech.

On that note, here are two concepts I've been reflecting on for some time, and I would love to explore with the FOC community:

1. A substrate for communication, collaboration, and coordination — built on our existing social graphs.

I've started using LinkedIn as a way to communicate above the walled garden chat communities.

I'm doing this to enable discoverability + accessibility + knowledge-sharing with my work. Much of the professional world — at least in subject areas I'm focused on — is on LinkedIn. By posting content and having discussions there, it enables anybody who may be interested in what I'm working on it to discover it — and likewise, me to discover them.

For this use case, and many others, it seems uncontroversial that we'll move away from centralized social networks — to networks that are more free, user-centric, and dynamic.

To start this transition, it seems that the simplest and surest first step is having access to our graph data — so that we can use it and build/experiment on it.

Specifically, I'm talking about:

1. Export my contacts from LinkedIn, Facebook, and other social networks, using their APIs
2. Import those contacts into a new substrate/protocol, with some simple structure to help with identification. (For example, to tell the difference between two contacts named "Bret Victor." Or, if each of us have a "Bret Victor" in our contacts, an intelligent way to recognize if they are or are not the same person. Email or phone number could be a useful "anchor" for this — and better approaches could certainly be possible as well. )
3. Once I have all of my contacts accessible — I just want some simple functionality to send messages, and the ability to tinker/experiment with new ways of interacting on top of this new substrate.
Part 1 is feasible today. Part 2 seems like it requires some dedicated thought and design. Part 3 only comes after Part 1, and along with Part 2.

If anybody is interested in this type of thing, I'd love to hear thoughts and collaborate. Note that this approach isn't about onboarding to a new network, it's about migrating our existing networks to a new and dynamic environment. Also this is envisioned more of a commons / protocol initiative, not as a new network itself.

2. A better browser — for embodied browsing, better bookmarking and tabs, configurable interfaces and websites, etc.

• A tool to use face / hand / motion tracking in front-ends and browsers
• New browser capabilities like tab management, privacy, custom macros, auto quitting tab processes when memory runs high
• Social bookmarking / knowledge management
• Modifying website interfaces
I want an open-source browser that starts pulling some of things capabilities together, makes them available, and enables us to keep building on top.

I want the embodied browsing experience of pulling my hand down through the air, like Luke Skywalker setting down the X-Wing on Dagobah, to scroll down on articles and feeds — turning computer time into embodied, physical activity.

When I have shit tons of tabs open, I want my browser to automatically quit the process of the oldest tabs — not x-ing them out, but just freeing up the memory — so I don't have to do that myself.

I want to experiment with social bookmarking, and I don't want to depend on an extension or a SaaS product to do it.

I want to be able to modify website interfaces — and have those preferences / customizations saved, for whenever I return.

I want to be able to experiment with digital virtual assistants and building my own automated processes — e.g. for specific websites as well.

There could be limitless other possibilities too — especially if the browser is open-source and configurable.

It seems like a lot of the tooling for this is already built out, either in extensions or in experimental GitHub repos. I am very okay with hacky and experimental.

I just want to start putting this together and start experimenting / building / seeing if there is anything viable here. I've never worked with browser software, and I'm not going to embark on that journey solo I don't think — so if anybody else wants these types of capabilities too, let's explore making them!
7 comments
# Maggie Appleton 2021-07-11 12:15 #
:wave: Hi folks. Surprised I didn’t find this community sooner, but glad this is a thing!

I’m an art director, designer, and mediocre dev in London. Also helped co-create a book that uses visual diagrams to explain javascript: justjavascript.com. That project sent me down the rabbit hole of researching visual programming languages and alternate programming mediums. I was already a Victor/Kay/Engelbart/Xanadu obsessive, so it all comes full circle.

I’m also a cultural anthropologist by training, and headed in an MSc in digital anthropology at UCL. Interested in the cultural dynamics of programming communities – specifically JavaScript-land since that’s where I tend to hang out. Glad to have found this corner of the web and always up for a chat with folks interested in the same topics.

# Wilhelm Klopp 2021-06-15 04:52 #
:wave: Hey folks! A friend pointed me towards this community a few months ago and I've been lurking since! Have slowly been making my way through some of the content (Whole Code Catalog and related) and still can't believe how much amazing stuff you all have gathered here. SO cool that this community exists! :sparkles:

Similarly to what I've seen in a couple of other introductions, I got hooked on the vision of a much better future after watching Inventing on Principle by Bret Victor. Spent some time investigating the space of "mobile apps for software engineers" for my bachelor thesis. Then worked at GitHub for a couple of years, mostly on and around the GitHub platform/API. Left that job to focus full time on building the @Simple Poll Slack app (which remains my primary income source but has little to do with the future of coding).

Over the past year I've been thinking a lot about how to make software engineering much much faster. This culminated in me building Kolo which brings some liveness/runtime inspection/visualisation to Django + VSCode. Kolo launched two weeks ago in alpha, so definitely still under heavy development and I'm taking in all the feedback I can. Hoping to contribute to the #two-minute-week channel on occasion! :crossed_fingers:Oh and I’m based in London! :gb:
# Nils Berg 2021-06-06 15:02 #
Hey all!
I'll preface all of this by saying I'm more of a futuristic coding enthusiast than an active researcher – I like listening to the podcast, I very much enjoy learning about different approaches to code, but at the end of the day, most if not all of my coding happens in regular old imperative textual languages.

That all said, my day job is not entirely unrelated (NDAs suck...), and I like to believe my combination of academic, professional and hobby interests should let me contribute some thoughts :slightly_smiling_face:

I did implement a behavior tree based "mission control" system (think http://philserver.bplaced.net/fbe/, but with behavior trees instead of statecharts) for my Master's Thesis, with some (sort of) unique tweaks particularly w.r.t. handling data and long-running actions – happy to share the PDF if anyone's interested.

Aside from that, some of my interests are:
• Hardware design (both circuits and chips, i.e. VHDL/Verilog) + low-level embedded (up to and including cycle counting) software
• Music/Rhythm games (think DDR or Rock Band), and the unconventional user interfaces that go along with those
• Niche programming languages (I at one point wrote an APL program, and started learning some Forth, to give you a taste)

# Jacob Chateau 2021-05-09 03:00 #
Hey there! I study math, physics, and compsci independently. My interests focus on the (shared!) foundations of math, physics, and language. I want to develop computationally-rich environments where communities can gather and transmute their collective knowledge and catalyze discovery, learning, and teaching.

I am also interested in programming language design. I am very interested in dependent type theory, homotopy theory, higher categories, and how these ideas will influence the future of computing on increasingly-varied material substrates. To this end, I am trying to reimagine the entire information architecture, from MOSFET microarchitecture all the way up the abstraction layers. To this end, I want to extend the idea of formal structure (especially as implemented in category theory and functional programming languages) to include "formal substance", and to leverage the understanding which this affords to make more efficient metamaterial substrates for the observation and control of information flow, generally.

I got into math to learn physics, and then I got into computer science when I learned that my category theory knowledge should overlap significantly with the functional programming paradigm. I am currently reading SICP and learning Scheme, taking a break from Haskell so that I can better understand compiler and interpreter design. I'd like to push high-level interpretation further down in abstraction, and to find how information flow relates fundamentally to the shapes of our programs as physical control processes.
6 comments
# Massimiliano Gubinelli 2021-05-02 08:43 #
Hi all. I'm a mathematician and computer languages enthusiast, interested in topics going from formal proofs, user interfaces for editing technical documents, manageable and open source software engineering, high-quality computer typography. I'm part of a group of people developing the free scientific editing platform TeXmacs (www.texmacs.org, https://twitter.com/gnu_texmacs) which is a complete solution for scientific document preparation and reproducible science including interactive sessions with external software. I'm here to look for possible collaborations/interactions with other projects which look forward into the evolution of our way to use computers to express, develop and publish ideas.
2 comments
# Jan Ruzicka 2021-04-27 10:17 #
Hi! I'm Jan, I'm about to begin my studies of mathematics, and I've always been keen on programming and more recently on an "upgraded version" thereof. I've come to discover this community through my readings of Alan Kay's ideas, and especially the Whole Code Catalog has amazed me.

During the past year, I've read much about synchronization in distributed systems, symbolic AI (the work of William Byrd and others has blown my mind) and much more, and I've been thinking about general human-computer interaction, especially in the realm of programming. My dream project is an environment for a hybrid textual-graphical language, in which one wouldn't generally write text, but rather compose entities that would both have behaviour (in regards to development) and signify behaviour (in regards to the end-product).

Right now, I'm finalizing my final high school project which entails the development of a library of trace-like versioned container types. These are designed for distributed systems, since they are CRDTs. I also plan a small declarative language that uses genetic algorithms to synthesise implementation fitting a type declaration together with a test suite. I'm also interested in (homotopy) type theory, and I'm exploring the problem of constructing simplicial types inside it (recently, I started thinking about speculative typing).

Anyway, I'm looking forward to discussing any ideas about the future of programming (and generally computer science).

# Braden Eliason 2021-04-08 20:19 #
Hello! I'm Braden. Trained as a biomedical engineer and spent my career developing medical devices. I'm currently an innovation fellow at the Medical Device Center at the University of Minnesota. It's a year-long leadership program to find an unmet medical problem and come up with a new device to address it. I'm was referred to the FoC slack from the Julia Discourse forum.

My main interest is accelerating the rate at which we (everyone) develop products. The frustrating reality for many product designers is solving a problem that has been solved before ... but the solution is inaccessible (paywalls, trade secrets, lost, forgotten, poorly documented). Some people shrug and say "that's just the way it works." I see this as an avoidable waste of the time and energy of many engineers, scientists, and designers. I think programming is a key element to addressing this problem.

@Molham Aref, I enjoyed your talk at JuliaCon 2020. I met a few people from relationalAI for beers ages ago, and it seems like you've curated an incredibly talented team.
3 comments
# Allen Webster 2021-04-07 21:05 #
Hi everyone! I am a developer, currently at Epic Games. My interest in development tools started with making 4coder, a text editor (that I still use now!). In the course of that project I realized I couldn't achieve most of the things I would want to because of the limits of the text-file-centric paradigm. Last year I started exploring how to build something outside of that paradigm with a small team and in my research I discovered the FoC community. I've been lurking on the edges since then. I'm interested to see more of what other people out there are doing.

# Kevin Greer 2021-04-05 14:46 #
Thirty-one years ago I had an idea about the future of coding, and since then I've directed my education, research and career towards realizing that vision. I've studied programming languages, compilers, modelling, knowledge representation, design patterns, functional programming, operating-systems, data-structures, and any other subject which I thought would contribute towards my goal. The current manifestation of this idea is called FOAM, the Feature-Oriented Active Modeller (see: foamdev.com). A short video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S4LbUv5FsGQ and a long one: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PsFLlgrzn2E. Besides that, I enjoy 3d printing, camping, playing go, slingshotting, and I coach track & field (pole vault).

# Reid Roman 2021-03-31 13:27 #

# Yusuke Shinyama 2021-03-28 19:01 #
Hello, my name is Yusuke Shinyama. I'm interested in program comprehension and education. I'm currently teaching introductory CS (Python) and AI/ML exercises at Tokyo Institute of Technology. Originally I've studied (and had a PhD on) Natural Language Processing, but eventually got bored of it so I moved into Software Engineering. Why? I've always been interested in studying the meaning of a language, but found out that so many NLP researchers are afraid of even using the word "meaning" because it's such a loaded word there! I assumed that the meaning in software world was a bit better defined... only to find out that the meaning of functions and identifiers are still very murky area here. Still, I hope to bring some of the insights I've got in NLP to the SE field. For now, I'm mainly working on a program comprehension of a large project. I also worked on developing assistive tools for blind people, and am interested in accessibility tools for blind programmers. My hobby is developing game engines and open source tools (https://github.com/euske). This community looks fun and I'm grateful to be here. Cheers!
Edit: typo on my university name - oops.

# Pablo Donato 2021-03-11 10:27 #
Hello everyone!

I'm Pablo, a first-year French PhD student based in Paris. I have a background in theoretical comp-sci, more specifically in logic, proof theory, and programming language theory. I'm doing my thesis under the supervision of Benjamin Werner, who already introduced himself in this channel yesterday :)

I have been following the FoC podcasts and weekly newsletter for almost two years, and always found the discussions and findings of the community very enlightening and motivating. There is such a feeling of validation when you discover that there is a whole community of like-minded people, who share similar vision and core values in the way they dream about the future of computing ^^

My long-term ambition is to help bringing together centuries of deep philosophical and mathematical knowledge about logic, and decades of experimentations and insights in the design of ergonomic human-computer interfaces. The ultimate goal being to build a solid foundation for a renewed science of programming, that focuses more on the human and social aspects of systems building. Yes, I might be too big of a dreamer, even for the FoC community :sweat_smile:

To conclude this lengthy introduction on a more concrete note: we are currently working with Benjamin and collaborators on the design of a new kind of graphical interface for proof assistants, based on the direct manipulation of mathematical objects and formulas. We may soon be able to share a very early version of our web-based prototype. We will then be eager to get feedback and insights from the FoC community! As a little teaser, I recently discovered that there may be a formal Curry-Howard correspondence between our work, and the one of Conal Elliott on tangible functional programming... Stay tuned for more info!
8 comments
# Rob Haisfield 2021-03-10 20:47 #
Hi, I’m Rob Haisfield. I’m a behavioral product strategy and gamification consultant, as well as a behavioral product strategist at Spark Wave. Basically that means that I think about how to influence user behavior such that people gain more value out of the apps that they use.

I’m largely in this group due to my work on the onboarding for GuidedTrack, a domain-specific language for interconnected form building --> web applications. Since working with them, I’ve become fascinated with powerful horizontal products with a smooth learning curve from beginner to power user, and domain-specific languages feel like the next natural step. There’s a lot that could be done to make DSLs learnable, even as replacements for full-blown apps, and I want to help make that happen!

You can find some of my work for GuidedTrack here:

https://robhaisfield.com/notes/guidedtrack

And if you want to skip ahead a bit for the full onboarding plan I presented them: https://robhaisfield.com/notes/onboarding-plan-as-presented-…

Hello ! I am Benjamin, a professor in CS and interested by formal proofs. That is having the computer manipulate and verify proofs. I am happy to join !

# Mark Probst 2021-03-05 09:06 #
Hi! I’m Mark, and for the past two and a half years I’ve been working on a commercial product to make software development dramatically easier. After working many years on programming languages and developer tools I’ve become more and more disenchanted with the current state of affairs. Building even simple apps seems to have become not easier over the past few decades, but harder. Spreadsheets, the most successful end-user programming tool, is stuck with a UI that makes it almost impossible to deliver nice apps. That’s one of the amazing but also frustrating thing about them: they’re the programming environment as well as the app you’re building rolled into one. So one of the ways to think about what my team and I are building is a spreadsheety database at the base that a configurable frontend at the top. I’m here to learn about people’s ideas and brainstorm. Thank you so much for having me!
# Ketan Agrawal 2021-03-01 16:22 #
Hi! I’m Ketan, and I’m mostly just here to lurk and take a glimpse into the future :) I’m currently a student, and one thing I’m interested in is embodied cognition as it applies to programming. I made a “smart glove,” and currently it helps me switch tools easily when drawing on my iPad, but I’m also wondering how I could use it to help me program. I’m also enthusiastic about emacs + org-mode (mixing code blocks from different languages!), and I am tinkering with a couple cute emacs-lisp packages for integrating twitter threads and spotify playlists into org-mode.

# Francois Laberge 2021-02-23 07:19 #
Hi everyone. I’m Francois. Here’s what I’m working towards. It is called Gooey. I'm going to blather a bit here, to see if any of my background is interesting for context.

My background is in making design/dev tools, platforms, and of course just making experiences. I was a game developer for the first 10 years of my career and then went on a decade run of doing startups. I work at Bose having done Applied Research in the XR/tools space for the last 3 years and now am being promoted into running all Software Incubation within our investment arm. Lately I've been more seriously experimenting and discussing getting funding to start a company around this space.

I can't share too much just yet, until I either get a legal waver from Bose Legal, and finish some discussions on potentially spinning out from Bose. I want to work on this no strings attached though.

Gooey's rough description and direction is: using game engine/editor technology but applied to refining and communication concepts to others. I'm a fan of a tool that is browser first and am pursuing that approach. I think highly baked in social features is extremely important. Figuring out how to make securely re-mixable components that will have access to often personal or professional data is top of mind. Other things I'm interested in:
How do you make interactive design code/assets that will still be runnable/loadable/useful in a decade (not be dependent on likely to go away environments like APIs)
Figuring out which is more optimal: being the whole runtime/IDE stack, being a more clean embedded runtime, or being more of a file-format/protocol.
Is there a conflict between learnable and powerful?
Creators can easily make an ecosystem of hard to understand building blocks and processes, is there something that can be done to help grow a culture of caring about crafting good remixable components such as static analysis or badges/scores marked by each component?
Should I make a new programming language or try to tame existing languages with some editor enforced invariant enforcement?
Ensuring components are say functionally pure, or a DAG, and/or deterministic for instance can lead to some serious optimizations, cleaner implementation, and I think learnability.
I'm a fan of for instance what Observable is doing where you can write Javascript with a minor language change or two, but it's difficult to not make your code reactive by default.
I'll stop there, I've thought about this for almost 15 years, so I could talk forever.

I'd like to build a sustainable/high-profitable company so I can have a healthy amount of funding to pursue necessary research with smart collaborators. I'm struggling with how to balance wanting to make something open source. I'd say I really like Figma's approach of just making something awesome people want to pay for, being a relatively open company sharing their design thinking, and of course I think the CTO making cool shit for the community (such as in esbuild). This makes me feel like Figma gives back to the community. Of course there is plenty of space for a magnitude more of giving back and being transparent, which is where I'd hope to fall. It's all easier said than done to make sure you aren't a starving idealist/artist.

My favorite company overall though (and I find this funny, after all of the hate I had when they were trying to kill the browser) is Microsoft in terms of vision for enabling developers both profitably and in giving back a lot with awesome open source projects. Github is in my opinion, the most well designed product ever.
1 comments
# Emil H 2021-02-20 13:50 #
Greetings from Gothenburg, Sweden! I started coding in Amiga Basic as a 10-year old, and professionally since 2000, mostly web, C++ and graphics. Although I always loved programming, I also always strongly felt that there has to be a better way than the status quo. Frustratingly, my teachers, colleagues & peers didn't seem to care. When I finally found Bret Victor's work, it felt like a huge validation - "I'm not alone, I'm not crazy, someone else gets it too!"

Consumed the Future of Coding site in "read-only mode" for years (thanks for the great content, Steve!), but I didn't join the community in read-write mode until now that I have something substantial to contribute - coming soon in the #share-your-work channel.

Interested in everything, but with a special focus on:
  • Visualization - as in revealing the shape and size of abstract things clearly, not just giving bar charts a sci-fi look
  • User interface design - really unhappy with current mainstream trends, UIs ought to empower users rather than dumbing things down
  • Pipe dreaming of redesigning OSes, the internet and the web stack from scratch with the benefit of hindsight
  • ... but also charting realistic incremental improvements
  • Green/environmental issues - neither hardware nor CPU cycles are free, make sure they carry their weight

    # bmitc 2021-01-28 13:33 #
    Hello! Most of my career has seen me working in a visual programming language, namely LabVIEW. Because of this experience, when I move to my other favorite languages like F# or Racket, it feels like 2 steps forward and 3 steps backwards, primarily when it comes to being able to debugging and especially while the program is running. I am inspired by visual languages like vvvv, Pure Data, and TouchDesigner, and I am convinced that the future of programming is a hybrid approach, where there is tight integration but blurred lines between what is textually and visually specified. I am learning Pure Data and vvvv at the moment, and still have it on my plate to learn Touch Designer and Pharo, all the while I am working on designing my own language while also learning how to generally do so. :) The trouble is I'm not the smartest tool in the shed, so progress is slow but becoming tangible.

    # Ash Nehru 2021-01-06 05:15 #
    Hello all ! @Tomas Petricek directed me here, thank you Tomas !
    My current job, which I've been doing for just under 20 years, involves using a mixture of C++, python, and various shader languages (GLSL, HLSL, DirectX compute et al), that runs on clusters of CPU+GPU machines. Over the years I've become increasingly frustrated with the (continually worsening) complexity and poor productivity of the tools we use to write such applications, so I decided to do something about it.
    For the last year, I've been working on a side-project called 'zero' - a programming language (and tool-chain) to let me write efficient, compiled, type-checked code that runs on the CPU and GPU, distributes across clusters naturally, but also gives me a proper live-coding workflow. Not a big ask, obviously :sweat_smile:
    I've got to the stage where I finally have a reference interpreter that lets me experiment with language ideas and workflows, and I'm about to start work on the full-on compiler. I'm in the fortunate position of being able shortly to transition to working on the language full-time, with a target of starting a new company in early 2022.
    Since I have an engineering rather than an academic background, I have a lot of learning to do - I definitely need some mentorship, guidance, critique, encouragement and moral support. Hopefully I can also be of some use to others as well !
    11 comments
    # Nikita Baksalyar 2021-01-05 10:47 #
    Hi folks! :wave: I'm delighted that a long chain of links from papers on visualisation and visual programming languages finally led me to discover this community.

    I'm enthusiastic about making systems programming more accessible and explorable. In particular, my goal is to bring more people into the Rust community and I'm working on applying some of the Bret Victor's and Papert's ideas in Low-Level Academy, which is intended to be a free & open resource to learn about things like networking, operating systems, or virtual memory in an interactive and project-based fashion.

    I'm also exploring ideas about making Rust documentation easier to understand, thinking about how to bring collaboration & sharing into the interactive playgrounds, how to make them a11y-friendly, and about how to find time to work on all this stuff. :smile:
    # Shubhadeep Roychowdhury 2021-01-04 04:47 #
    Hello Channel,

    I am Shubhadeep. Indian by birth and presently living in Paris (moving to India in Feb 2021). I have been working as CTO of Codist for the last one year and half (EF pre-seed funded). We have been working on Machine Learning on Source Code and built amazing open source products including docly (Auto document your python code), tree-hugger (Universal Source Code mining platform), CodeBERT (a transformer model, pre-trained on code corpus).

    Before that I have been working on Very Large Scale data Engineering and Machine Learning in Companies such as Kpler (Paris), Ubble (Paris), Mammoth Analytics (SF/Bangalore), Experience Commerce (presently part of Samsung) etc.

    I have really wide range of experience and expertise. Some of them

    - Vast ML and DL skills including clear understanding about the theory behind (Created product from scratch which is Open Source and used by more than 500 active users in less than three months)
    - Data Engineering (Beam, Spark, Kafka, AWS, GCP, Elasticsearch)
    - Dev-ops (Docker, K8S, ECS, Ansible)
    - Programming Language (Python, Go, C++, Rust, Javascript)
    - REST API, Scrapping, Architecture Design
    - Building and maintaining a team, mentoring them
    - Internationally published author in Data Science https://www.packtpub.com/product/data-wrangling-with-python/9781789800111
    - Highly popular tech blogger - https://medium.com/@rcshubha

    Some of my profiles / Other online presence -

    Github - https://github.com/rcshubhadeep
    Stackoverflow - https://stackoverflow.com/users/1587118/src#
    Linkedin - https://www.linkedin.com/in/shubhadeep-roychowdhury/
    Youtube - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2d-w3cx2TlU&feature=youtu.be (my talk on Machine Learning on Source Code in a very popular DS channel)

    What am Looking for? -

    With a heavy heart I have to bid goodbye to Codist. We did all we could. But despite being good engineers / scientists, we were not good sellers. So at the end we accepted the reality that we are out of money and no-one is yet ready to invest (Oh you, God d**n COVID!). So, I am looking to get a suitable senior position (CTO, Lead Data Scientist, Senior ML Engineer etc.)  in a well funded start-up.

    I am ready to join whenever is good for you.

    I will be fully remote (unless you have office in Goa, India)

    Contractual or normal job both welcome. But I am mainly looking for financial  reward more than ESOP kind of things.

    I have worked in remote first teams for a good part of my life, so don't worry I know what I am doing.

    I can always adjust my schedule with you.

    I will be travelling in Feb so there will be a period of about three weeks when I won't be working. (I can start after that, if that suits you better)

    I am more than happy to have a virtual coffee with you if you think that is worth it. And I am looking forward to join an exciting organisation, solving a meaningful and challenging problem.

    I am also attaching my CV with this message. And I wish you all a very happy new year ahead! :tada:

    # Vladyslav Sitalo 2021-01-03 17:27 #
    Hi everyone, I’m Vlad currently SDE @ Amazon.
    I’m fascinated by a cluster of things that the following labels approximately points at: Tools For thought, Cognitive Augmentation, Novel HCI approaches, future of programming, personal data infrastructure
    Also “malleable software” as I quite enjoy building things that have an immediate impact on my experience of using computers.
    And I’m interested in making it easier for people to do that/coming up with ways to make our environment more hackable in general.
    Most of my popular OSS work is around enhancing the tools in the areas above (https://github.com/roam-unofficial/roam-toolkit, https://github.com/Stvad/CrowdAnki etc)
    Another thing I find fascinating is DSLs (with focus on internal ones). I did a talk on what kind of delightful things you can do to Python to make it better suitable for writing DSLs (https://twitter.com/VladyslavSitalo/status/1344539651818758144?s=20 )
    -
    I’m currently trying to figure out how to work on something within that cluster of things full time. So if people have recommendations for companies they find fascinating in the area - I’d appreciate if you can share them :)

    # Daniel Worthington 2020-12-10 10:46 #
    :wave: Hello! I'm Daniel, and my passion is for design tools. Specifically, I’m very interested in tools that allow designers to have more autonomy, allowing them to ship things and freeing them from relying on engineers. I’m a designer and engineer myself, currently working at InVision as an engineer on the Design System Manager team.

    My big project at the moment is to articulate the vision I have been working on for the last few years in a meaningful way. It’s all about making it possible for designers to build user interfaces and collaborate with engineers rather than draw pictures of things and then “hand off” to engineers. Realizing this vision would involve creating several new tools, and — maybe more important — a new way of thinking about what designers are responsible for and how they collaborate with engineers.

    # Fred 2020-11-27 10:10 #
    Hi everyone, my name is Fred, I'm 24 and live in the uk.

    I've spent the last year obsessively thinking about some crazy idea I had, of representing an application as a graph data structure, in which everything (ui, logic, state, assets, everything) can be boiled down to edges and vertices. I thought this was the basis to do so many interesting things like code generators, low-code type tool, and even the theory behind it.

    I never knew that there was a whole active community behind a lot of the ideas I've been thinking about. This has blown me away, made my entire day, even. I've never spoken about this type of stuff to anyone because I never thought anyone would even care, but to see that I was completely wrong is awesome!

    Honestly, I haven't worked on my project for ages, after being busied by personal issues, but the past few days going through all the work and information from this community really revitalised something. All of a sudden, it's all I can think about again.

    I don't have anything to show yet, but hopefully I'll share progress with you guys soon. I don't really know what else to say in this post, so I'll leave it at that :woman-shrugging:

    Good day
    5 comments
    # Greg Caban 2020-11-24 04:40 #
    Hello Everyone,
    My name is Greg and I’m a software engineer at Adzerk, where I get to code in Clojure, doing backend development and data engineering. Big fan of Lisp, Functional Programming and PL topics in general, with a keen interest in how FOC ideas can make data exploration and analysis easier and more accessible for everyone, including non programmers.
    Few years ago I had a chance to work on Mathematica inspired custom language with Notebook based UI and backed by Hadoop Data Lake, built as a data exploration platform for a financial institution and it was quite an eye opening experience.
    I’m very excited to discover that there is a community of people sharing the dissatisfaction with current state of programming and dedicated to exploring ideas on how to improve its future!
    6 comments
    # Paul Chiusano 2020-11-23 11:34 #
    Hi everyone! I'm Paul, one of the creators of the Unison language (https://unisonweb.org). Happy to be here!

    A while ago I did experimentation with a structured editor for Unison where syntax and even type errors were ruled out by construction. It was neat but it raised a lot of questions about how to make the experience nice enough to actually use for real editing. For Unison, we came up with a very nice way to make codebase-level edits and refactoring without ever going through broken states, but for editing or writing individual definitions, I think it's harder to displace text editing (even though the benefits to doing so are huge).

    I've enjoyed following along over the years with @Cyrus Omar work on Hazel and @Eyal Lotem's work on Lamdu, among others, and glad to see people making more progress on this stuff. The Unison team is looking to pick up this topic of structured editing again soon now that Unison's core language is getting more settled (we're working on getting a non-alpha release of Unison soon). So maybe there will be opportunities to collaborate with folks here. :slightly_smiling_face:
    4 comments

    # Aria Minaei 2020-11-13 04:41 #
    Hey folks, I'm Aria :wave:

    Like most people here, I daydream FOC ideas :smile: I'm usually thinking about the gaps that separate groups of people, and how tools and languages can bridge those gaps.

    I've been trying to do this as my job since 2014, but only managed to get there three years ago. I've been funding it with consulting, grants, and two very helpful angel investors.

    What I'm working on is an authoring environment where developers and designers make things together. I usually describe it as a design tool that "blurs the line between designer/developer, author/consumer, and artist/scientist." If that sounds lofty, it's because it is. Right now it's just a modest animation editor for web apps that can be used by both designers and developers.

    Short-term, it scratches an old itch. I always wanted to draw and code the same kind of stuff.

    Long-term, I think this kind of environment (one that bridges manual and procedural creation), can be a building block to other FOC applications, like data/interactive journalism, exploratory learning, and trans-disciplinary authoring environments.

    Also as a side-project, I'm building a personal memex. (who isn't? :man-shrugging:)

    Anyway, I'm always up for a call to bounce ideas :blush:

    # John Soo 2020-11-01 07:36 #
    Hello I’m John. I live in Southern California and I currently write a lot of rust on the front and backend of an ad exchange. I have written PureScript, elm and Haskell previously. I love the future of programming. There are three or four topics that are at the top of my mind recently: types as visual design, polymorphic version control and diffing, type theories for tierless distributed computing, and user operations and self hosting with functional package management.

    # Luifer De Pombo 2020-10-29 11:02 #
    Hi everyone, I'm Luis. I'm originally from Colombia, but have lived in the Bay Area for many years. I worked as a software / infrastructure engineer at startups and bigger companies for a while and have often had to rewrite backends to be more efficient or scalable. I dream of a day in which the same program/backend can run on a single core or across many machines in the cloud without any operational complexity (extra deployment configuration or maintenance), extra code (frameworks or vendor APIs) or constraints (delayed execution, limited runtime, no persistent connections, etc). I created a new programming language with a friend to see if we could create a compiled language with a simplified bytecode, wrt to traditional languages which allow arbitrary computation that is not guaranteed to halt, that could be automatically parallelized by a VM/runtime (written in Rust :crab:) based on the size and shape of the data. It is still very much in an alpha state, but lmk if you want to learn more or have feedback for us!
    https://github.com/alantech/alan
    1 comments

    # Danny Zuckerman 2020-09-30 06:03 #
    Hi all :wave:

    Been lurking here for a while and finally introducing myself (and hopefully getting more active). I'm one of the founders of 3Box, where we've been building a 'decentralized firebase' that lets apps and services store data with users rather than on siloed servers. We're now focused on Ceramic Network - a verifiable information network and 'dataweb' (as opposed to siloed database) - and identity index library for managing identities, users, and other information across any app and platform.

    We're really aimed at helping infrastructure and developers that are ushering in a more open, composable, connected web -- which is so many of you here. Happy to talk about anything related to identity, dweb and composable apps and looking forward to continuing to see and learn from your projects and thinking :slightly_smiling_face:

    # Dennis Heihoff 2020-09-26 08:09 #
    Oops just saw in the member handbook and #administrivia I should’ve first posted here. So:
    > tell us about your background
    Originally I got into coding through film. I was preparing for auditions for my first feature. Upon posting a casting notice online I got over 4000 submissions. I had hardly any $$ so I couldn’t hire casting agents or assistants. At that time I started to dabble in coding, mostly making small games like battleship. I realized I could use google sheets + gscript (JS-like scripting around gsuite products) to send emails. I exported all actors data into a CSV, imported it into sheets, rated actors based on their video reels and fit for the role.
    Then wrote a 80 line script that sent them personalized emails in which, if their rating was high, they’d be invited to a scheduled audition and when low to an open call. The emails were signed by a made up person “Janina Kebera - Production Office Assistant.” I hacked on the script for 3 days, then pressed a button and it sent 4000+ emails in less than a second.
    I got 20 responses in 2 minutes, 40 in 5. I ended up doing the auditions but never the movie. My experience with it was so impactful, I decided to pursue coding instead.
    Since then I made Vimsical, root, genetic algorithms for CSS, trading algorithms, GRID and a few other projects.

    > what your interests are
    While learning about genetic algorithms I stumbled upon the concept of fitness functions and made my own. It’s “have fun and be curious.” This gets me around.

    > how you got into computer futurism
    I don’t know if I have. I think we got ahead of ourselves. The future lies in the past.

    how you found the Slack
    > I got introduced to Steve Krouse in the early days of FoC
    interesting hobbies
    > only code makes it online :wink: so here’s my github
    Really love skimming through the posts here. People are up to amazing stuff! Feedback is constructive, people help providing context through links etc. Thanks everyone and especially @Ivan Reese for all your hard work on FoC.
    1 comments

    # Cameron King 2020-08-10 12:33 #
    Hello all. I'm Cameron. I found this place in a roundabout way--surfing Chris Granger's Twitter, he retweeted John Edwards who linked to Steve Krouse's Patreon, and enough link-surfing got me here. I'm currently unemployed, but my skills are in full-stack web development. To give you a sense of what interests me, a while ago I put out a project that reduces most conceptual operations on Vue components to 4 or 5 keystrokes made from anywhere in the file, and right now I'm experimenting in the world of self-editing web applications. It's actually surprisingly easy. I built my feasibility prototype as a Rollup plugin for Svelte projects, and it's only ~200 lines to start live-editing the application in place using the same underlying tech as the developer. As a next step, right now I'm exploring what developer tooling looks like when there's no longer any distinction between "editor" and "application".

    # Jack Rusher 2020-07-20 01:12 #
    As I'm participating more I should probably do this...

    I've been programming since the 1970s. Originally focused on physics and mathematics, I was lured astray by certain findings in theoretical computer science. This is my 35th year as a Lisper and Emacs user. My first purely functional programming language was Miranda, c. 1987.

    My desert island programming languages are Scheme, FORTH, Smalltalk and ML (Prolog's features are better as a library), but my most used language since 2009 is Clojure.

    While I prefer to use highly interactive languages, I've also written millions of lines of C code in the course of my career, which has included all sorts of things from building operating systems, clustered filesystems and high-performance language runtimes to creating the first purpose-built Triplestore for the semantic web to building some of the earliest streaming databases and complex event processing systems to building a big document understanding system using a mix of modern statistical and classical GOFAI techniques (most recent startup exit).

    @Ivan Reese interviewed me for the podcast last summer:

    https://futureofcoding.org/episodes/041.html

    At university I also studied classical music composition and played guitar in the jazz orchestra. Some years later, while doing a startup in the Valley, I attended art school at night. If you're interested in some recent work at the intersection of art + tech, here's a talk I gave last autumn in Helsinki:

    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TeXCvh5X5w0

    Looking forward to getting to know everyone. :slightly_smiling_face:
    1 comments

I mostly view code as a tool to accomplish specific real-life objectives, though I do enjoy sharpening the coding knife. I run r/LearnJavaScript on reddit, too, and have been idly working on a book about breaking into the coding industry (free at https://ZeroToCode.today, people with CS degrees may shudder at some of the commentary). I’ve also been teaching myself to draw, so the book has a lot of very good amateur illustrations.

    18 comments
    # Tim Plotnikov 2020-07-11 05:07 #
    Hello everyone :wave:
    My name is Tim and I’ve found this community through the Future of coding podcast, episode about relational algebra.

    I was always interested in such things like frame-based editing, new ways to program a computer, etc. And I couldn’t imagine that there is a community who also explore “future of coding” :grin:
    I’m really excited to be here!

    Now I’m exploring the idea to apply relational model to managing state in mobile applications. The main goal is to make mobile app development easier, less error prone and reduce amount of code that mobile developers usually write.

    I’m not sure why, but currently mobile applications usually contain SO much code and accidentall complexity that it blows my mind. An app for mobile phone can easily grow to millions of lines of code for moderate functionality and I’m believe we can do better.

    I’ve started with Rich Hickey’s talks and “Out of the tar pit” paper and we’ll see where I can get with it.
    3 comments
    # Tor 2020-07-11 01:38 #
    Hello! I made an account here some time ago but I don’t think I ever posted anything. I’ve been listening to the podcast now and then for the past few years. I’m an interaction designer and front-end developer interested in systems and how they shape work.

    I’m currently working on a collaborative JSON editor. I have some future-of-coding-ish ideas that I want to explore in the design, around how to make schemas and automation more accessible to typical users.
    # Jeff Mickey 2020-07-06 13:13 #

    My name is Jeff Mickey, and I'm an IRL friend of @Tom Lieber's. I really like defmacro, let over lambda, and really anything to do with code generation. My current project is building a templating system for guile scheme that allows for the data / code divide to become smaller similar to imatix's gsl project. Hope to post some updates about my progress in a while.

    # nicolas decoster 2020-06-29 06:44 #
    Hi!
     
    I have already posted some "introduction" more than one year ago, but as today is a kind of "coming out" for me, I post a new one (or at least an update)! :slightly_smiling_face:
     
    In fact after very busy months on some cool-but-not-FoC-related project, today I start my 100% Future of Programming life. From now on, I will be fully committed in exploring, experimenting, state-of-the-arting, discussing and, of course, building stuff in this very exiting field. I have some ideas to experiment, old prototypes to reconsider (and throw away again after picking the good parts), users to meet, existing tools and languages to explore, etc.
     
    Here are some quick words on the vision of what I would like to work on. At a very high level, it is all about tools for thought, tools to create, tools to share ideas, tools to program. More concretely, I plan to work on collaborative programming environments usable by non experts. With a focus on how to provide the more expressive/tangible/interactive/malleable views of programming artifacts. As first "proglet" representations, I am thinking to explore two well-known and successful visual ones: blocks à la Scratch and nodes'n wires à la Max/MSP. But with the ability to still use text languages when the visual ones are not appropriate (yet). As they are widespread and covers most of the technical needs, all this will first be based on web standards, which will also ease adoption and meet some common first usages. Another "minor" reason, is that I actually enjoy programming in JavaScript (and even more in Vue.js)! Ok, ok, I can hear half of you saying "oh, nooo! not the web again" and the other half saying "obviously!", while a third half (hopefully, the bigger of the three halves) doesn't understand those petty squabbles. :smile:
     
    My background is nearly 30 years of professional programming on a wide range of fields (front/back/DB/infra/science/viz/GUI...), five years as an educator for creative computing with kids and adult beginners (mainly with Scratch) and a bit of programming for music/audio (with Live and MaxMSP) some times ago.
     
    Of course, I hope to be more active in this community (especially, compared to recently). I will be very happy to read and discuss all the very interesting subjects that you all are sharing here (some I have missed recently)!
    5 comments
    # Joe Nash 2020-06-29 03:02 #
    Howdy folks :wave:
    I’m Joe, and I stumbled onto this community via my work with Enso (which some of you may know as Luna language), thanks to Ivan and Mariano on twitter :smile: I work on community and education (docs etc) at enso, but have long been interested in programming language design and Haskell, which is how I came to meet the Enso folks. In the past I’ve spent a lot of time working on initiatives to help young folks, particularly students, learn to code, via Major League Hacking, and GitHub Education.

    # Blaine Buxton 2020-06-28 07:42 #
    I stumbled on to "Future of Coding" podcast through an interest in Orca for music. I've been making my way backwards through the podcast and feel like I've found my community. I've long been frustrated with programming tools after I left Smalltalk professionally. There's something to a lively environment that old Lisp and Smalltalk systems gave you. I have always wanted to get "modern" tools up to that standard where you thought only of the problem you were trying to solve. My goal is experiment with keeping focus on the task at hand and not the idiosyncrasies of the language or IDE. Excited to find like minded individuals and hope to participate in the future with others on projects.
    3 comments
    # Ray Imber 2020-06-27 23:10 #
    I'm a long time listener and big fan of the podcast, but I'm just now getting around to joining the slack. I'm a big fan of Bret Victor (like many here I'm sure). I love experimental programming language design and compiler theory. I'm heavily involved in the nim-lang community, my niche language of choice. Where I differ from the mainstream is that I am not a fan of the modern web. I'm a big fan of Jonathan Blow, Casey Muratori, the "handmade" movement, and the ideas of "mechanical sympathy". I favor returning to native apps over web technologies everywhere. I feel like I'm a weirdo for being interested in both "the future of code" and also interested in low level computer optimization, but I believe it's possible to have the best of both worlds (at least that's my dream)! I am more about "raising the ceiling" than "lowering the floor" of programming. I come down firmly on the belief that computers are like a musical instrument, and we don't need to dumb them down (and slow them down) with an ever growing pile of abstractions, we instead need to provide a structured ladder of abstractions that can enable more expression. I will probably spend most of my time lurking, but I'm excited to be here and see what everyone is working on!
    15 comments
    # Andrew F 2020-06-27 21:30 #
    I just discovered this Slack while trawling r/programminglanguages! I'm hoping to meet some people with similar interests to mine. I'm an idealistic software developer who keeps getting distracted from actual projects by thinking about how cool computing could be if our tools were better. I usually view language design as part of a continuum with API design, OS design, and databases. Currently in the DC area. Looking forward to talking with you all!

    # Aleks Litynski 2020-06-16 14:39 #
    I've been posting a few things, so I feel like its time for me to drop an introduction in here. My name is Aleks. I'm a software engineer living and working in Massachusetts. I went to school for game development, but fell in love with programming languages and web development along the way. I'm interested in building tools that make computers easier to use without paving over the underlying complexity of computing. I believe when there's a dissonance between what a program appears to be doing and what a computer is actually doing, it causes pain all up and down the stack - from end users to the folks designing the silicon.

    I have a terrible track record of leaving projects unfinished, but I will include a link here to one of my more finished projects - a command line tool for working with tags the same way you would work with files. https://github.com/alekslitynski/tagsystem. Like everyone else here, I'm currently hacking on a visual programming system. I'm hoping to get it to a point in the next few months where other people could jump on board and participate in its development, if they want to.

    This community seems wonderful, and I'm excited to dive into it.
    3 comments

    Hi all!
    I'm a web applications developer.     # Oliver Caldwell 2020-06-15 04:47 #
    Hey! I’m Ollie, a language and text editor nerd writing Clojure for fun and profit! Currently at Viasat hacking on parens.

    I’ve been working on interactive programming tools for Vim for the last few years, my pride and joy so far is Conjure (https://github.com/Olical/conjure), interactive lisp evaluation for Neovim. The primary language is Clojure but it also supports Fennel and Janet with Common Lisp potentially being the first contributed client! https://asciinema.org/a/325517

    This work got me interested in the general concept of having a conversation with your program so I wrote that up here: https://oli.me.uk/conversational-software-development/

    And now I have an itch to develop a 3D spatial non-text programming environment with stepping / time travel through the execution of the program based on ClojureScript in the browser. Another goal of this is full VR support where you’re exploring the program in space. The program itself would eventually be exportable and runnable wherever you wanted. This is an experimental concept that I don’t intend to be used in anger, but I want it to be good enough to solve Advent of Code problems, for example.

    After ranting about this on twitter I was directed here and I’m so glad to have discovered you! :smile:
    34 comments

    # Robert Butler 2020-05-30 16:25 #
    Hi everyone! I'm Robert. I'm working on designing a hobbyist processor architecture that is designed to fit in a single person's head. The ultimate goal is to get a full software stack sitting on top of it that is useful from micro-controllers to serious desktop processing, simple enough to be fully understandable by a single human mind and yet powerful enough to do so-called "real" work. I basically want to figure out how simple we can make our entire software stack and perhaps unlock even more potential in the world by doing so.

    # Zach Potter 2020-05-27 12:38 #
    Hey everyone, long time lurker here! I'm a software engineer in San Francisco. Over the last couple years, I've been playing with a handful of flow-based programming tools and prototyping my own. My main interest is in tools that make programming more accessible to everyone, especially those without technical backgrounds. I believe that the flow paradigm is intuitive and flexible enough to become a mainstream interface that everyone can use to manage their data, devices, etc.

    I started working as a fullstack eng at Parabola.io just a couple months ago. It's a web-based flow tool for connecting and processing data from a wide range of other cloud platforms. Think flow programming meets IFTTT meets Excel. It's been an interesting shift in mindset, going from daydreaming about a flowy future to building a product that needs to solve practical needs for users! :slightly_smiling_face: It's a fun challenge, and I hope to share a few insights in the future!

    Hopefully you'll see me jump into some conversations around Slack and Twitter. And if you're playing with Parabola, I'd love to know what you think. Please reach out if you need a hand with anything (tech issues, feature requests, pricing, etc)

    # jeff tang 2020-04-28 09:36 #
    Helloo, I’m Jeff. Been lurking here for a month or so but after reading the community survey transcript I realized I should speak up. You see, my current FoC project is building an open-source version of Roam Research, but I’m mainly just doing this to learn Clojure. Why? Because what I really want to make is a chat client built on top of a graph database that supports bi-directional links and multiple indexes (i.e. chronologically of course but also by tags that can organically emerge as channels similar to Zulip).

    Conversation is personally my favorite Tool for Thought, but we haven’t quite cracked it digitally. Can we have frictionless divergent streams, but also refined, retrievable evergreen posts? This message by @Mariano Guerra sums it up so well, and I have to agree… I’d be so sad if I never found it! Looking forward to continuing the conversation :wink: here and on Twitter if you’re into that sort of thing

    Hey everyone,
    I'm a gamedev at an indie studio and before my bg was in real time raytracing research. Currently to me, the solution to those goals converged to imperative programming with a functional core, relational code architectures (e.g. in games ECS over OOP). I just discovered "Language oriented design/projectional editors" which seem to be the final missing piece so I'm excited to dive more

    # Chris Martens 2020-03-08 06:41 #
    Hello everyone! My pronouns are they/them. I direct research on games/narrative/interactive systems and teach computer science at NC State. I spend a lot of time thinking about making better tools for game development & other forms of expressive computing, combining Programming Languages and HCI approaches. This includes how language design (models of computation) influence how creators think about creative possibility spaces, and about how game design and HCI principles can make programming a more playful, expressive, and joyful experience. My academic website is here: https://sites.google.com/ncsu.edu/cmartens?authuser=2

    # Chris Maughan 2020-03-05 09:48 #
    Hi, I'm a GPU Programmer. In my spare time I'm working on a live coding environment. The integrated editor was the first job (https://github.com/cmaughan/zep); It has interesting features such as GPU and Qt renderers, and the ability to embed widgets inside the text - it is designed to cleanly support the features I'm going to need in the live coding environment, while allowing me to live code using optional Vim syntax. The live code part isn't open sourced yet, but I'm hoping to get at least the graphics side of things out the door within the next 6 months. The renderer can sample audio using FFT etc and respond to music. I also have an experimental synthesizer along with a work in progress Orca front end to it. Lots of toys, no time to build them - but I'm making steady progress... :wink:
    19 comments

    # Matija Sosic 2020-02-26 03:45 #

    # Grigory Hatsevich 2020-02-14 10:39 #
    Thanks for creating this community! I am excited to get to know people here and work together!

    motivation
    • I'm looking for a programming environment where I can go from an idea to an implementation as quickly as possible.
    domain of interest
    • I am interested in tools which enable sophisticated end-users to build their own interfaces and functionality to manage their data and social networks, discover like-minded people and collaborate with them effectively.
    • I have a particular app/system I want to build — "Network of trust". It can solve the problem of fake accounts (my presentation: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qZJ-BercOGg) and also enables you to weigh opinions of different people by trustworthiness of these people derived from trust chains from you to this or that person in the corresponding competence area. (I see it as a solution to what Alan Kay once wrote about: "the [information] retrieval systems of the future are not going to retrieve facts but points of view" https://vk.com/trustnet?w=wall-56630573_84_r91)
    ideal
    • I want the highest-level programming that is possible: I communicate to an IDE my intentions (goals, restrictions, preferences) and the IDE gives me a working version of a program satisfying these conditions, which I then can customize and try using, then update my intentions and go to the next iteration, etc.
    some wishes
    • Functionality discovery right in the IDE, integrated with external sources (libraries, APIs). When I want to do something but yet do not know how to do it in this particular language, the IDE should be helpful to find that out (instead of googling manually). Ideally the solutions thus found should be already plugged-in and working with my actual data without the need for manually setting them up. E.g. when I want to plot a bar chart from my data, the IDE fetches several libraries that can do that (sorted by some ranking of relevancy and quality) and shows me the actual results of these options (with my actual data) so I can choose which I like more.
    • I can organize my code spatially (in 2D or even 3D). So that when I want to edit my program, I always know where to look for relevant parts of code to edit or add to.
    • Structured code editing, with the impossibility of syntax errors. Ability to select and edit whole semantic entities instead of just editing text characters. Convenient refactoring.
    programming experience
    • I learned a bit of Pharo Smalltalk, then made some projects with Javascript and Node.js (https://hatsevich.ru/programming_portfolio.html). Working in Pharo IDE was much more convenient then editing text files (javascript/node.js). Maybe I should return to it and use it for backend — unless you point me to something better.
    some thoughts on programming I wrote earlier
    • "Why programming languages are broken and how we can fix them" https://www.facebook.com/g.hatsevich/posts/742023955927813
    • "Tool-oriented programming" https://www.facebook.com/g.hatsevich/posts/741820789281463
    Interesting links on the "perfect programming" topic I found I posted here: https://vk.com/perfect_programming
    2 comments

I understand that the no code movement has some bad rep in this community, and I (and we) are not threatened by that. I'm excited to learn more about and discuss the future of programming and computing with you all!
    http://highgear.com

    # Joseph Ivie 2020-01-31 18:24 #
    Hello! I wish I would have found this forever ago - I'm a software engineer that's extremely interested in programming language design, and I'm currently working on a language concept (deterministic, metaprogramming, and code-completable editing).

    I got interested in programming languages while working extensively on various libraries for mobile/back-end/web (Kotlin), as I frequently found myself fighting language limitations to make the most intuitive and simple API possible. I've made a simple scripting language in the past, and I've managed my way around ANTLR while making a Kotlin to Swift syntax translator.

    I've sure been humbled just reading about the various concepts I've never considered before, especially coding with proofs. I also feel a little out of my depth with some of the formal terms here, but I'm excited to learn from you all!
