    # mat ess 2020-01-30 16:42 #
    hello all!

    im a software engineer by trade but very interested in forward looking programming languages as a hobby.

    im not sure exactly how i stumbled across this slack, but i have been lurking the programminglanguages subreddit for awhile and believe i saw it linked there.

    i was drawn to the topic of programming language design and theory by my experimentation with haskell over the years, and the intense curiosity i found in the haskell community for pushing the language to its limits. since then i have consistently been very drawn to various functional languages, particularly purely functional stuff. the recent thing that has been interesting me is algebraic effects, particularly in the ability system provided by unisonweb.org. i have been doing some tentative explorations into a lambda calculus based language myself, drawing inspiration from haskell, unison, reasonml/ocaml, and to a lesser extent, idris, purescript, etc. the syntax will probably be somewhat divergent from the traditions of these languages, as i am interested in seeing how the lambda calculus can be made more approachable for people used to c, java, javascript, python, etc
    16 comments
    # Josh Cho 2020-01-26 21:05 #
    My main interests are in psychology/introspection/meditation, which if programming=thought, then programming=emotions, programming=pain/pleasure (or to be more precise expressions of emotions, expressions of pain, expressions of any psychic content).

    So tools for thought could also be tools for emotions. Emotions are just nonverbal thoughts, anyway. I hope all this progress that we have made with tools where you can see your own ideas => can be propagated to tools where you can see your own psychological conflicts and problems.

    Art has been doing this for millennia (representing our psyche), why can't interactive computing environments do it? Anyhow glad to join

    # Mike Travers 2020-01-25 10:00 #
    Hi everyone, I՚m Mike, and I՚ve been interested in making programming expressive and accessible for a rather long time. I was at the MIT Media Lab in its early days, working on the Vivarium Project, and also invented a visual block language that was one of the ancestors of Scratch. Since then I՚ve mostly been working on software to support scientific discovery, currently at the Parker Institute for Cancer Immunotherapy. These include an early web-based notebook/VPL system called BioBike and most recently a block-based tool for building queries against knowledge graphs[*]. Most of my work is done in Clojure and before that, Common Lisp. I՚m excited to see so much new energy being devoted to improving the experience of programming.

    # Colby Gutierrez-Kraybill 2020-01-21 10:24 #
    Hi, I'm Colby, I've been working on the Scratch backend systems since 2015, starting with the MIT Media Lab and we have just moved out of MIT and are officially in our own Scratch Foundation org. My coding history started in 1989 using Borland Turbo Pascal, and has been cross systems/paradigms since that point and in no particular order Perl to Ruby, Python, Java, C, C++, Go, Node, assembly, JavaScript, my own DSLs, and of course Scratch. My current focus is supporting the deluge of Scratch users needs. Long term, I'm hoping to help incorporate Scratch into a cross compiler/cross platform frameworks that allows the ability to use Scratch in much broader contexts. I am based in the Boston MA area. And I was brought here by someone else on the Scratch team!

    Hi there! I'm Tuomas, and the author of Operon.io -language. I have played with different programming languages for 30+ years, and felt that the existing languages don't work as I would like them to work, on the real life problems related on my field of integration. I created the initial website for the project, as a starting point for the release process (http://operon.io). I haven't yet released the binaries and most of the documentation is yet to be written :grin: I joined here as I felt the purpose of this community is aligned with my mission. I hope to share my thoughts with you, reach some of you to both give and receive feedback. After the project is mature enough I will start to reach out for larger audience. Cheers! :smile:

    # Tony Fortunato 2019-12-19 18:12 #
    Hey All, I'm Tony. I'm a former EE turned robotics engineer. Been programming since I was a kid as a hobby, but my only formal CS class in school was done in scheme (and it definitely shows!). It's been a long path, but I've moved my way from doing Analog IC's to Embedded Systems to now, where I am part of a team building a platform for distributed soft real-time control of robotic systems that are reactive to their environment. It's a super exciting project because we get to explore a ton of neat areas, both old and new, and enable folks to rapidly put together systems that interact with the real world. Not very often you get to see a guy writing code for a safety PLC discussing an electrical interface with an engineer doing reinforcement learning over high-res pointclouds on a multi-nvidia card box, and they are working on the same project!

    Also turns out that the experience I had making block diagrams of signal processing chains and communicating modules, or state machines I made for behavior as an EE might map pretty nicely to mechanisms I'm learning about in the CS world if I call them FRP, or Actor systems, or state charts. And who doesn't love a graphical editor, whether it be for schematics or a distributed system :slightly_smiling_face:

    Anyways, I'm in love with the creativity that is out there, and how many other folks are also thinking about how we move coding beyond where it is now. It's often overwhelming for a dilettante like me :-) I'm excited to learn more about what's out there, and to personally up my CS chops and learn some more theory. And of course very excited to share what I can with all of you as well!

    # Kai Richard König 2019-10-28 08:29 #
    Hi all, long time lurker here. I love this community; it has so much valuable content and discussions; it also gave us confidence that we were moving in the right direction. As we are getting ready to launch what we (https://bitspark.de/) have been working on, I want to introduce our company Bitspark. We started working on a VPL long before we knew that this community existed and where navie enough to not even search for prior art - doh’. We started from an observation we made as everyday programmers. There so much repetition, and you need to be highly trained to be a software engineer. We asked our selves what the world after Programming would look like. That was in early 2018. Since then, we created a VPL runtime (https://bitspark.de/slang/) in Golang, making heavy use of Green Threads (each node in the tree is a green thread all connected via channels). That gave us quite the performance out of the box (https://bitspark.de/blog/benchmarking-slang). We have had our ups and downs and doubts and in the process, went through three different (editor) UIs. And then, in early 2019, we decided we need to build a platform around the runtime and the UI to make it easier to access and run/manage.

    And that is what we (soft) launch in early November.
    Why am I telling you this? We are looking for like-minded people willing to take the platform for a test drive and provide valuable feedback or provide feedback in any form or shape. (https://bitspark.de/#private-beta)
    20 comments

    Hi Everyone, I have been working with @Maeliza for the last few months to try to build CodistAI. Developer for last 15/16 years. Started doing Game Development in India back in 2005. Then drifted to Web Application and Machine Learning Engineer. Also super interested into Quantum Computing. I write time to time for towardsdatascience.com (https://medium.com/@rcshubha) and working on open sourcing a bunch of notebooks on QC (https://github.com/rcshubhadeep/qc4cs) I am very happy to join the channel and looking forward to learn a lot.     P.S. - I also got published from Packt this year - (https://www.packtpub.com/eu/application-development/data-wrangling-python)

    Hi everyone!

    I want to make the process of coding closer to how we think about programming. I'm currently experimenting with structural/projectional code editors. I am also fascinated by how structural editors open a window for new programming languages unburdened from text-based syntax.

    # Maeliza 2019-10-25 14:25 #
    Hey there! :wave:
    I've been working with a friend on CodistAI (http://codist-ai.com/) for the past two months: it's about navigating and understanding source code in visual and more intuitive way. We render any code as a graph which is diggable, interactive and augmented (with quality and security info).
    We came up with that idea bc working on different projects and every time the same question "WTF is happening here ?!" especially when I face some kind of spaghetti code.
    Also I'm deeply interested in any way possible to make software development more dev friendly! :nerd_face:

    I'm happy to join this channel!
    4 comments
    # Tibor Halter 2019-10-25 06:06 #
    Hi all! I've been working on a web development platform called Boomla for 14 years, I'm sort of coming out of the bush these days. https://boomla.com/ I also call it a Website OS as it is a platform where websites are first-class citizens.
    It is a server-side platform, with its own object-oriented filesystem, functional execution model, package management solution, etc. It can currently be programmed in JavaScript on the server, but it will support multiple languages in the future.
    It also provides a drag&drop user-interface for end-users to let them build websites. But that's optional, you could build a different frontend for it.
    It has a web based IDE and lots of documentation. I made the decision early to focus on the platform and not write any new programming language. :smile:
    It was designed to be low on maintenance. The platform is fast and rock solid stable. Developers tend to agree that the most interesting part of the system is the object oriented filesystem with lots of interesting properties.
    I'm glad for the existence of the group, looking forward to interesting conversations!
    10 comments

    # Ed Baskerville 2019-10-24 15:33 #
    Hi everybody! I’m yet another child of HyperCard hoping to recapture the dream of the ’90s. I’m currently working with @Peter Abrahamsen on an end-user thing; we’re experimenting with building it using a simple Datalog-like model.
    Divergently, I’ve spent a lot of time in academia building ecological and evolutionary models, all the while dreaming about more natural ways for scientists to work with computers. (And doing basically nothing about it.)
    Less concretely, I’m generally hopeful for a future where many more people view computers as infinitely flexible instruments of creative expression rather than devices limited by what professional software developers are willing to provide.
    I’m also interested in how power structures in society have affected the way we use computers—and what we can do about it.
    I’m here for the conversations!

    # Eric Hanson 2019-10-15 16:15 #
    Hi folks, I'm a long time fan of Edwards and Victor, and the guy behind the aquameta project ( http://aquameta.org ), trying to prove the concept of (for lack of a better name) "datafication" of the stack. Aquameta reimplements the layers of a traditional web stack as relational data, so that rows instead of files are the atomic unit. As an industry, we are really good at building user interfaces to data, and if the whole stack is data, UI that manipulates it very easy to develop. Explorinng concepts around version control of relational data, datafication of EBNF grammars for data-driven code manipulation from a UI, semantic decoration of the database schema to couple UI components with columns for auto-crud generation that can be progressively enhanced, an on-screen in-app widget editor so that you can edit a UI from within the UI, etc. Demo videos: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZOpj8lvNJtg&t=4s and https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r8SYrTmUXgU
    16 comments
    # Eric Casteleijn 2019-10-11 09:45 #
    Hi all. I'm interested in safer, easier to use programming languages. I suppose like many here, I was fascinated by Bret Victor's famous presentation, and I've been following another series of interesting attempts at https://alarmingdevelopment.org/. Discovered the podcast recently, and hope to find more thought provoking resources here. (I don't think I'm going to attempt to build something myself anytime soon, but one never knows.)
    2 comments
    # Edward de Jong 2019-10-11 00:18 #
    You have done such a great job of making things pretty, and routing the wires nicely. But I think you have picked the wrong level of abstraction to diagram. You are drawing the microscopic local variables, yet in a program like Snake or TicTacToe (see https://github.com/magicmouse/beads-examples
    ), one has the core model stored in some data structure which holds the source of truth, which for TicTacToe might be whose turn it is, what is in the 9 cells of the grid, etc., then you have the layout of the screen, which has its own data structures, and then you have user input events, which are not data but a stream of inputs driving the finite state machine of the game. There is negligible computation in this example, and if you diagram the functions you would make it less understandable. I like visual tools, but diagramming local variables and formal parameter inputs is too low level IMHO. Lots of things one could draw nicely, but the low level computation is perhaps the least interesting thing to show.
    # Robbie Gleichman 2019-10-10 23:07 #
    @Dan Cook Yes, the eventual goal is for Glance to become a code editor/debugger for Haskell or other languages. Currently, Glance drawings don't scale well to large and/or complicated functions, so I have been thinking about how to improve that recently. I think adding a more structured and linearized node layout (in addition to the current layout) with lines/wires routed in a more organized fashion might work. Right now I'm attempting to prototype the new layout by taking textual Haskell code and adding ASCII art lines to it.
    # Dan Cook 2019-10-10 17:47 #
    Hey, I've seen this before - I think listed on @Ivan Reese's visual programming codex?

    Anyway, that's a really neat visualization! Do you have any plans to allow "programming" to be done by direct interaction with such visualizations?
    # Robbie Gleichman 2019-10-10 16:34 #
    Hi, I'm interested in visual programming languages, and how they could make harnessing computers more enjoyable and accessible for everyone. I have been experimenting with represeting Haskell visually as a way to figure out what the biggest barriers are towards making visual programming languages universally useful: https://github.com/rgleichman/glance.

    # Dan Cook 2019-09-18 23:17 #
    Stumbled upon Jim Coplien's work with DCI
    -> He talks a lot about Alan Kay
    -> became a fan of Alan Kay and found VPRI
    -> subscribed to the VPRI mailing list
    -> when the list was discontinued, many subscribers replied with disappointment and made our own projects known
    -> I made the SomethingNew GitHub repo as a place to collaborate and catalog our ideas
    -> people kept adding resources and links, and we started stumbling across other online collections and communities (like Ivan Reese's)
    -> Eventually wound up here, but didn't do much and kept wandering and forgot about it
    -> Eventually found Dark, and Ellen Chisa (CEO) referred me back to here
    -> Discovered that many other individuals and groups I had come across previously (big names and small) and whom I never thought were connected or that I'd come across again ... Many of them are part of FOC, so I concluded that this is some nexus of it all and became active here

    Like @Steve Krouse, I am curious which route people took in finding this Slack. My own route was similar to @Luke Persola:

    I was reminded about @Jonathan Edwards's work on Subtext →
    Looked over his blog for a bit →

    Joined this community
    # Luke Persola 2019-09-15 19:20 #
    :wave: Hi all. I’ve been doing web dev for six years.

    Googling Elixir/Erlang stuff →
    somehow @Jonathan Edwards’s Vimeo channel →
    his interview on the podcast →
    this Slack workspace

    I’ve never formally studied PL theory/postsecondary math/really anything related, but I’ve skimmed the first page and a half of a lot of PDFs. Like others here, I’m dogged by persistent fantasies about how my programming experiences could be improved, which for me tends to lead to thinking about language user interface design and how programmers experience the meaning of code (so semantics, but in the original sense?). My on-again, off-again pet project is a structure editor that uses color and shape to convey syntax but largely retains the visual layout of text editors.

    # Ian Rumac 2019-09-12 00:47 #
    Hi everyone!
    Just found this community via Steve’s HN post.
    I’m Ian from Croatia, I work as a software architect in an agency primarily focused on mobile development. Been into code generation since I was a kid since I’m too lazy to write code the “normal” way :joy:
    Currently working on a “code editor” (I like to call it a software editor or a list editor, like treenotation designer), using kotlin and tornadofx mostly - You starts from the datatypes, workflow connections (visual connect the dots) and ends up with a generated graphql w axon-kafka or molecular.js backend and a flutter mobile app (that’s kinda the MVP goal) but I want it to be language-independent. Basically, I want it to be to IDE’s what Lisp is to Java My current minigoal is to use it to write the editor itself, that’s gonna be a PITA in itself but I think I might have it in a month or so.     # Sean Thielen 2019-09-10 13:58 #
    Hi! Saw the catalogue post on HN and found it super interesting :slightly_smiling_face: I'm one of the cofounders of https://withkoji.com , a web-based IDE + hosting platform trying to make it easier for non-devs and junior devs to create games and web apps (JS or JS-flavored things) by remixing existing apps and then using a combination of code and no-code interfaces to create something new. We're fresh out of beta, and already have a ton of different people from all around the world and all walks of life creating all kinds of weird things -- the goal is to do to app development what YouTube did to video publishing. Some more info here: https://venturebeat.com/2019/04/23/gometa-raises-6-million-a… and here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BgpFGMH6VR4 (long technical video). Anyway, excited to have found this community and look forward to participating more!

    # Ernest Lee 2019-09-10 11:16 #
    Hi, I contribute to the game engine Godot Engine. We cater to the surface level understanding of the game designers who barely code, to the gameplay developers who care about games than the complexity of a rendering engine, to the game engine developers who have to provide understanding of all the cases but don't have bandwidth to dedicate to being a gameplay developer.

    In Godot Engine, we have several coding interfaces. C++ core, C++ as a shared library GDNative, GDScript which is a custom python-like game script, and Visual Script which is a Node and Wire graphical editor. https://godotengine.org/

    I and a Google summer of code student have been improving Visual Script from it's current unusable state. https://godotengine.org/article/gsoc-2019-progress-report-3#visual-scripting The work has been done, but it's not fully merged yet. Godot Engine is not just capable of games, imagine using a single executable editor / game for other things!
    1 comments

    # Scott Werner 2019-09-09 13:34 #
    Hi everybody, I just found this community today through the Whole Code Catalog that was getting shared on Twitter, adding the podcast to my list as well. I’m an engineer working on design and prototyping of voice user interfaces at Adobe, primarily on Adobe Xd and previously at my startup Sayspring that focused on Alexa and Google Home.

    Tend to stick to HN and Twitter (@scottwernerd), and ran into @Kartik Agaram online a while back through Ribbonfarm and his blog. Actually got into an argument the other day around code style that ended with me sending someone a link to one of your old blog posts :slightly_smiling_face:

    Anyway, current side project is working on an idea around reading and exploring code I got from the end of The Timeless Way of Building. I don’t have the book with me, but the drawings on the right side on page 488 are the key idea - being able to visualize how code evolves over time at different levels (project, file, class, function, etc). I’m still in the early stages, so don’t really know if anything interesting is going to fall out, but happy to chat more if that sounds interesting to anyone.

    # Don Abrams 2019-09-09 02:32 #
    Howdy everyone, I'm an American living in Paris very interested in democratizing the development of apps and programs. My current controversial opinions/hypotheses are that in most companies design and product really do most of the "programming" (but little of the coding), developers have developed internal models of the subsets of Turing machines that behave well but we haven't made those explicit, and category theory may provide a useful way to model programs and guarantee properties under composition (but currently feels primarily descriptive).
    7 comments

    # Breck Yunits 2019-08-30 08:40 #
    If anyone is visiting Oahu and wants to grab a coffee at the cancer center, shoot me an email breck7@gmail.com or yunits@hawaii.edu
    # Breck Yunits 2019-08-30 08:38 #
    Aloha everyone. I'm Breck, a researcher at the UH Cancer Center Honolulu. My main communities these days are HN, Lobsters, /r/programminglanguages/, and SUS. I work on Tree Notation and am creating the Tree Notation Lab here. Our theory is there is a natural notation sitting between binary notation and higher level languages that has been overlooked and it could be a silver bullet. We call it Tree Notation and it's very promising (though we might have some details wrong---always looking for help). To be thorough, we build the largest database of programming and computer languages in the world with over 10K languages and over 1K columns (in the process of open sourcing it!). The first key applications we are working on is for a new data science language and studio for cancer/bioinformatics researchers, and a new grammar for electronic medical records. We are also helping over 30 companies now experiment with new languages in domains from tax returns to logic languages to visual ides and new languages for deep learning. DC referred me to this community and it looks very cool! I have never gotten into the Slack habit, so I apologize for noob mistakes.
    82 comments
    # Izu 2019-08-29 07:15 #
    Hi everyone! I’m Izu. I’m a developer and product designer, currently at Mailchimp, and have had an intense fascination with interfaces and the democratization of computing for as long as I can remember.

    I fully believe that to expand access to the computer’s nature as an interactive medium, we have to provide tools beyond code that enable everyone to take part, just as Photoshop did for image editing or the typewriter did for text, and I’ve been working on a project with just that in mind. However, I’ve been in a silo on this and I’m just beginning to discover all of the incredible research and resources out there around visual programming and conveying interaction beyond code.

    I can’t wait to hear more about the ideas for what’s next that y’all are working on. :pray:
    3 comments
    # J. Ryan Stinnett 2019-08-28 15:59 #
    Hi all, I am engineer in industry for a while, but lately I am getting more involved in research as well and trying to find the right blend for myself. My main communities these days are Mozilla, LLVM, and Matrix. I recently moved from Chicago to London.

    I believe mainstream computing has failed to deliver on many of the ways it could be empowering everyone in society (not just specialist programmers) and enabling communities to create and share specialised solutions to long-tail problems that improve their daily lives. I am exploring various approaches to restore some of the magic that's been lost. More thoughts on my blog: https://convolv.es/blog/now.html

    # Edward de Jong 2019-08-25 21:01 #
    would be interested in how one adds a new language to syntax highlighting for VS Code. Some of the new languages being developed are textual and even many of the graphical ones have a textual output, so making it clearer how one gets syntax highlighting and of even more integration with VS Code, which is a very well received editor, would be helpful. People develop strong preferences for specific editors, and all younger programmers are used to partial completion suggestions and coloration.
    11 comments
    # Pine Wu 2019-08-25 20:56 #
    Hello there! My name is Pine and I'm an engineer at Microsoft working on VS Code. I have a short blurb about myself here: http://blog.matsu.io/about. I'm not sure how I ended up here, maybe because of the Bret Victor fan club thing, maybe because I sit below the TypeScript team room and Mr. Hejlsberg's influence seeped through the ceiling, or maybe because of the actually really good podcasts by Steve — anyway, nice to be here :stuck_out_tongue:

    In my work I maintain the HTML/CSS Language Servers in VS Code, and for fun I'm building the Vue Language Server (https://vuejs.github.io/vetur/). I feel Language Server Protocol is one of the interesting/new area of focuses in the language design/tooling space, and I'm exploring with programming tools that complement programming languages & enable new paradigms of programming. I see many interesting conversations and links floating around, and I look forward to joining the discussions!

    I'm based in Seattle but would travel to London/Tokyo/NYC soon. To borrow the tweet from ep35, if you are inspired by the Bret Victor talk, or the topics of LSP & programming editors/tools, I'd love to meet you over coffee. Coffee is on me :wink:
    17 comments

    # Amin Dorostanian 2019-07-31 02:59 #
    Hello people,
    I found this community while searching for people who are into Flow-Based Programming projects. I am working on a DSL to build up my own FBP over Kotlin. One of the main problems with FBP I faced so far is "Performance Issues". Since you are dealing with some way of communication among the blocks of codes (typically a protocol over socket). I wonder how others see FBP as a general purpose way of coding while dealing with it's disadvantages like performance issues.
    7 comments
    # William Taysom 2019-07-29 19:59 #
    @Brendan Zabarauskas something about dependent types feels icky to me. It's taken reflection over years, but it boils down to principle typing being a sweet spot where you can ask what is the type of an expression. Knowing additional properties is nice, but there's finesse: what additional type information is relevant for a given task. For example, within a library you really want to know that data-structure invariants are maintained, but as the user of the library you're happy to ignore those details.
    9 comments
    # Brendan Zabarauskas 2019-07-29 03:45 #
    @Pezo - Zoltan Peto I’ve actually been pretty fortunate to land a job working on implementing a dependently typed DSL at my job (because my boss is excited about them). But yeah, the more you dig into trying to implement them, the more you realise how much we still need to figure out in order to make them viable. I’m still pretty hopeful though. There’s lots of cool work going on at the moment, especially in the realm of modal type theory, and I’m hoping some of it starts coming together in cool, practical ways!

    My advice is to keep plugging away learning, and talk about it online like you’re doing. You might be surprised who you bump into! But it will probably be more of a case of ‘putting yourself in a position to be lucky’, and networking, than finding a job advertised explicitly.
    1 comments
    # Steven Shaw 2019-07-28 14:56 #
    @Pezo - Zoltan Peto dependent types are the future but it's perhaps a little difficult to make money at it right now (some folks are making money in the commercial realm proving things with the likes of Coq). In Haskell there are ways of simulating dependent types (https://personal.cis.strath.ac.uk/conor.mcbride/pub/hasochism.pdf). I'm not sure there is any Haskell<->Unity integration. Looks like Haskell will get full dependent types in the next few years.

    As you may not be able to use Haskell for your Unity work, I recall seeing this some time ago:

    https://twitter.com/steshaw/status/775271713940475905
    Some more tweets here: https://twitter.com/search?q=%20unity3d%20idris&src=typed_query

    I'd never heard of that integration before or since. I can't imagine it's maintained. Idris is a research PL with little funding ATM. Idris v2 is currently under development. I hope it has a bright future.
    1 comments

    # Pezo - Zoltan Peto 2019-07-15 08:50 #
    Hi everyone! I have just posted this question to hackernews and got to the frontpage. One of the comments suggested this channel but I don't really know anyone. (https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=20431879)

    I am 26, have a BSc in computers science. I did not go further to MSc, because I deeply felt my university does not emphasize the right things. Eg. we barely learned about FP and nothing on Dependent Types, but my interest was always to write the cleanest and most expressive code possible.

    I tried to look up and search many things in the last years: OOP, Uncle Bobs Clean Code series, classic GoF Design Patterns, DCI Architecture, Prolog and Logic programming, UML, Statecharts, reading on FP & Type Systems, research on Temporal Logic and model validation, TDD, property based testing, using (runtime) assertions to reason, Eiffel and Design By Contract. None of these made me happy, I always felt something is just missing. My intuition said it is closely related to logic, reasoning, and boolean "tagging" of values/objects as "properties" (how to model odd/even numbers), the support of incremental implementation of code, plus a huge one: some help/reasoning on ordering of computations: aka taming async code which might get complicated really quickly... and of course some neat IDE support for that: neat "views" to focus on different but related parts of the implemented code and study their relations with or without other logic statements already coded up.

    2 years ago I have found a youtube video on Idris and Dependent Types from Edward Brady and I was fascinated. I've seen the "properties" part I was looking for, the holes in code and some awesome self-written definitions, awesome case split. I googled Dependent Types, I have found Agda, Coq and Idris, checked some videos about them, but I was not sure if they are what I am really looking for or is there something more. This lead me to write the Ask HN post I mentioned above, I wanted to make sure I am not missing anything before investing in learning Dependent Types.

    After reading the comments and connecting some dots I think the main intuitions I had are addressed exactly by Dependent Types, but I am really curious about further/other ideas what are going on, plus to join to a community who might use these tools.

    I am wondering about the jobs and the fit of Dependent Types for my personal projects. I am a game developer now (Unity), but before that I used React / React Native, I am really interested in bindings with these technologies, but maybe it is not even necessary. I'd really happy to learn about real world options, how/where to use DT to make some money.
    17 comments

    # Kochise 2019-07-11 02:52 #
    Hi all, invited by @Duncan Cragg after I contacted him about his Onex project I found a few months ago. From my interest in astronomy, found http://www.projectrho.com/public_html/rocket/futurelang.php and Lojban, then Clean. As a basic/assembler/c++ coder, I discovered functional programming. Then I looked for LISP, quickly found Erlang, then Racket. My latest discoveries are Picat and Elm (and perhaps Pyret). Always had a problem with programming language verbosity, how much "useless" lines have to be input before getting actual things done. Java someone ? Anyway, thinking about my own programming language for years now, something more about declarative programming (Picat) but that can be also edited visually. Hence my interest in Onex and TreeSheets (from @Wouter van Oortmerssen ). I really like the spreadsheet representation that can already be found in property sheets, close to data base editing. Wanna add data ? Add columns/rows. Wanna change the code ? Add more formulas. And the underlying code is still textual and can be edited using a terminal and/or refactored/analyzed using standard tools. I'd like to avoid the culprit programming languages such like Labview of Windev that needs a proprietary, complex and heavyweight IDE to edit/compile the code. My main aim is ai, db and embedded coding. I like easy prototyping languages like Python, interpreted and/or fast to compile, easy to debug. Also greatly interested/influenced by Bret Victor's work on real-time feedback user interfaces. So, here I am, and thanks for the invitation.

    # Alan Zaffetti 2019-07-09 10:18 #
    Hi all! Longtime follower and recent contributor on the “robust first” computing effort with @Dave Ackley. My background is working in the industry on large software systems. I’m determined to build life-like robustness into a new computing stack. As a concrete analogy: I like to think of how primitive cellular functions build upon each other to achieve higher level goals. This could be similar to how traditional software functions are composed today. The best part is we get to start from scratch. Removing billions of years of cruft :-) we can build crisp and predictable functions with good reuse. That’s part of the fun and challenge of this work, and we’re definitely still at the beginning. Would love to get to know you all and answer questions!

    Edit: I hang out in: #robust-computation and http://gitter.im/t2tile/ is where most of the real work happens.
    4 comments

    # Joel Holdbrooks 2019-07-05 11:31 #
    Hello everyone! My name is Joel and I was directed here by an acquaintance who felt I’d fit in with this crowd. :slightly_smiling_face: I would consider myself as someone who’s relatively young in the PL space but have just as much love and respect for the field as any veteran out there. I’m primarily interested in Term Rewriting, Pattern Matching/Substitution, and Symbolic programming. For the past few years I’ve been developing a library in Clojure to do “real programming” heavily based on those interests. I believe there’s tremendous benefit in bringing TR concepts into mainstream software engineering, technical and social.

    # Anthony Di Franco 2019-07-03 13:35 #
    Hi all, I've come this way because @Kartik Agaram pointed out @Dave Ackley's work to me via a mention by Venkat Rao whose ribbonfarm.com blog cult we're both part of. I have a background in control and systems theory and information theory and I've been working on a kind of closed-loop approach to declarative programming. This has involved defining a progress measure for a computation in terms of an information-gain game between the system and the logic/environment, and an adaptive evaluation procedure based on trying to maximize performance in this game. More concretely, it's a probabilistic relational language written in Julia that uses ideas from game tree search to learn to do well at that game. The main strategy for optimizing is finding highly informative inference paths connecting facts to queries, which are essentially dataflows, so I got some ideas about a dataflow-oriented but still general purpose VM/hardware which I'm calling the Route Machine and which I think might synergize quite well with the Movable Feast Machine ideas. Looking forward to discussing more.
    I also enjoyed a quick look at the podcast backlog and am keen on taking in more of the culture. I've been a bit dry since Lambda the Ultimate declined in activity.
    16 comments
    # Dave Ackley 2019-06-22 11:06 #
    Hi folks. I'm here at the invitation of David Broderick, who liked a "Future of Programming" video I did a few years ago. I started coding on the IBM 1130 in the early '70s and my first programming language stuff was doing the code generator for (what became) the "Sargasso C" compiler for TOPS-10/-20 in the late '70s. I did machine learning in the '80s, artificial life and distributed systems in the '90s, and biological approaches to computer security in the '00s. Since about 2008 I've been on a mission to develop a computer architecture that abandons the assumption of hardware determinism and instead embraces best-effort throughout a reinvented computational stack. The resulting "Movable Feast Machine" looks like a cellular automata on steroids and we are only at the beginnings of developing basic structures and programming paradigms for it.
    9 comments

    # Josh Marinacci 2019-06-17 13:46 #
    Hello everyone.
    I found Steve Krouse’s podcast, and then to this Slack. In my day job I’m a developer evangelist for Mixed Reality at Mozilla, but I’ve had programming languages and usability as a passion of mine for many years. A lot stems from my belief that the best technology is something which empowers people to solve their own problems. The computer was supposed to be “the bicycle for the mind”, and yet it’s getting less hackable and customizable over time. There is such enormous potential in providing programmability to people who are experts in something other than programming.

    Also, I think there has to be a better way to program computers than ascii text stored on disk. Surely when we build the Starship Enterprise in 300 years it won’t still have a command line in it. Right? :slightly_smiling_face:
    8 comments
    # Ache 2019-06-06 15:33 #
    Hi!

    Consider a 3D animated character. How to build one such that it moves by itself? Then, how to make it such as it becomes a proxy for you to express your emotions and experiences, as quickly as possible, with as little indirection as possible?

    My interest in programming and computer as a medium comes from these first set of questions. My name is Achraf ("ash-rough"), I live in Morocco, and I have a background in visual arts, philosophy, and cognitive science. I worked in 3D visualization, web programming, and user interface design. More info on my website: https://www.achrafkassioui.com/

    I follow a lot of people in this group. Kudos to all of you who share and communicate your work.

    # Rashad Gover 2019-05-23 19:50 #
    Hello all. My name is Rashad Gover and I’m a second year college student in L.A. I’m primarily interested in functional programming, logic programming, denotational semantics, PLT, type theory, applied category theory, and the formal verification of programs. My main goals are to improve the ergonomics of programming languages, come up with methods for mathematically proving the correctness of programs, and come up with better ways of teaching programming and computer science. I am still new to a lot of this stuff so I look forward to learning a lot from the more experienced members of this group. I look forward to doing 1-on-1’s with some of you:grin: Cheers to the future of coding:beers:

    # Daniel Hines 2019-05-18 14:09 #
    Hello all. I figure it’s time I should formally introduce myself. I’m a programmer in Virginia who’s eagerly looking for the future of coding. My dream is to unlock the power of computing for non-programmers. I’ve seen this done particularly well in Dynamics CRM, Microsoft Excel, and in the now-abandoned Eve language. I’m particularly interested in logic programming, query languages (like Datalog), and the semantic web, so naturally I pay close attention to Dustin Getz’ Hyperfiddle project. Clojure is my weapon of choice, but I’m developing an appreciation for static types and the expressivity they bring, and am interested in exploring formal methods and dependently-typed languages like Idris. I also have an avid interest in how philosophy bears on computation, and how a humane philosophy can work itself out into humane software. I’m very grateful to have found this group. Here’s to the future of coding :clinking_glasses:

    # Sébastien 2019-05-16 05:59 #
    Hi there! I'm Sébastien and am currently based in Montréal (moving to Wellington, NZ in a few months). I've been interested in PL design since late 90s and have created a few transpilers ([Sugar](https://github.com/sebastien/sugar), [Sugar 2](https://github.com/sebastien/sugar2), [PAML](https://github.com/sebastien/paml), [PCSS](https://github.com/sebastien/pcss] as well as underlying tools/libraries like [LambdaFactory](https://github.com/sebastien/lambdafactory) and [Libparsing](https://github.com/sebastien/libparsing)). My background is primarily in software engineering, but I also have studied design and have worked at the intersection of both creating interactive data-visualizations and data-rich interfaces at [FFunction](https://ffctn.com)

    I'm currently working on two PL-related projects at the moment: Curved, a visual editor for the Curv Language by Doug Moen (who's also on this forum) and TLang, a language for incremental tree processing to build compilers, build systems, reactive user interfaces, databases and other applications that rely heavily on a graph structure.

    I'm very interested in the topics of visual programming and how programming languages/paradigms shape our mental model, and I'm particularly interested in the technical topics of parsing, abstract program model/program representation and data structure synthesis (all of which, you can guess, are quite useful in building modern compilers!).
    9 comments

    # Ian Bicking 2019-05-13 11:46 #
    Hi! I’m Ian (but you could tell that already), from Minneapolis.

    I’m particularly interested in programming environments – for instance, notebook interfaces seem like the most notable programming exploration of the moment. But the specific project I’ve been mulling over and experimenting with is using fully automated testing (like fuzzing) of interactive applications to collect execution information to support the programmer. I imagine a system where you can get a map of what the application actually does (intentional or not), and then you can explore down into why it does those things.

    But it’s a side project, so maybe more dream than reality, but I’m sure I’m not alone :wink:

    # Edward de Jong 2019-05-12 03:08 #
    i am working myself on something that would be ideal for coding camps, and i look forward to the field test where i test it on 12 year olds and 70 year olds. Both groups are excluded at present, and the seniors have the most to offer because they know what should be built, while kids typically only know games.
    7 comments
    # Edward de Jong 2019-05-12 03:07 #
    welcome to the group. There is no question that better languages can drastically simplify programming, and that a much larger number of personality types can enjoy programming once this grand simplification occurs. I find at present, programming is restricted to people who could do a 5000 piece jigsaw puzzle. That takes a very special kind of persistence, patience, and strong pattern recognition skills. Most puzzles sold are in the 300 / 500 / 1000 piece sizes, and many stores don't even stock a 5000 piece jigsaw.
    1 comments
    # Nathan Schulzke 2019-05-11 10:56 #
    Hi, all! My name is Nathan Schulzke. I first started programming as a 10-year-old with a copy of Macromedia Flash. Building silly Flash games as a pre-teen doesn't look like much of an educational experience to typical modern educators, but I firmly attribute my success in learning math, logic, and linguistics to early experiments in programming. Because coding was so foundational for me, it has always been surprising and disappointing how few kids get into programming, and how many CS college students find little to no enjoyment in it.

    Two summers ago I taught at a coding camp, which proved to be a turning point for me. I was able to observe in others the same transformation that I went through upon learning programming. I watched kids who thought they were dunces realized they could make the computer do anything, which gave them hope and confidence that wasn't there before. But I also observed that the programming curriculum we were given actually got in they way of learning, and only the few kids who were able to ignore the curriculum actually learned to love to code.

    This observation led me to read everything I could find on teaching programming to kids. I read Seymour Papert, Alan Kay, and Brett Victor, and a philosophy of programming education began to take shape. I began to feel that programming could be used to solve critical educational deficits in a lot of kids, if we can only lift our vision above the C-style programming model and treat computing as the wide and varied creative field it can be. I thought I was alone in this line of thinking until the Hillel Wayne podcast ended up on Hacker News. I'm thrilled to find a group so invested in all of my favorite authors, and am excited to learn more!
    4 comments

Would love to connect with anyone who believes we need a much higher level language to define data-flow that moves data in a highly readable and intuitive way. :heart: OSS, We are hiring!, See thread for details.

    # Pete Vilter 2019-05-09 09:11 #
    Hi folks! I'm Pete. My background is as a fullstack developer, but I've become very interested in databases, since a lot of fullstack app development comes down to loading and saving data from the DB. I've been working on https://github.com/vilterp/treesql, a database which has GraphQL-inspired tree-structured queries, and pushes out updates to those queries when the underlying data changes.

    I work at https://www.cockroachlabs.com/, where I'm learning the craft of database architecture from some of the greats. A few years ago, I also made some contributions to the Elm time-travelling debugger (https://github.com/elm-lang/elm-reactor/pull/115), so I have a soft spot for that project :slightly_smiling_face:

    # Charlie 2019-05-07 20:56 #
    Hi, I'm Charlie, and I've just released the Strat Cloud Language ( https://strat.world/ ). Strat is this odd thing that connects functions together within the cloud and lets users represent services and events at a very high level. I've just found my way here and I'm starting to poke around. As silly as it may be, I believe Strat, or other languages like it will play a big part in "the future of coding". Let me know what you think! Also, I built Strat's compiler in flat, (mostly) dependency-less Javascript, so if you want some deranged hot takes and poor technology evaluations, I'm your guy.

    # Dustin Getz 2019-05-06 06:27 #
    Hello, I’m the CEO of http://www.hyperfiddle.net/ which is a FOC startup currently based in Philadelphia. Hyperfiddle basically takes the Clojure/Datomic information model and extends it through to user interfaces. While the technology is interesting, we think a large part of the work is forming a strategy to get adoption at scale (a smooth path from 0 to 1 to 100 to 100k) and also figuring out an economic model to fund the work.

    We are bullish on Clojure because Clojure satisfies the criteria of “smooth adoption path” and has a lot of deeply interesting properties, such as the cost of porting Clojure to a new platform is within about a man-year of effort. Clojure on N platforms makes it possible to build distributed systems across platforms with shared information model, data structures and code. A unified/holistic model. So while Clojure is certainly not perfect, it is designed for real-world usage and makes practical compromises to achieve growth. We see Hyperfiddle as just one component of a self-organizing movement which is larger than any one project or company funding 100% of the work.
    7 comments
    # Liesbeth De Mol 2019-05-03 02:58 #
    Hi all, I am an art historian turned philosopher and historian of computing – . I was lucky enough to get a permanent research position at a time when I was starting to despair a bit and still feel as one of the most lucky persons when I realize I have this job. It gave me a new kind of freedom which I didn’t have in previous academic positions; and it took me quite a while to realize that. I am very much engaged with retracing and rendering transparent through history where we are now with computing technology – as so many others; I worry a lot about this broad and disconnected field; I very much like an approach of asking rather basic questions (I guess that is the philosopher in me) which, at first sight, almost seem trivial but once one starts to dig a bit, seem to be quite hard. One main question I am currently focusing on is: What is a (computer) program? This is the guiding question of a research project I am coordinating and which involves historians, philosophers, computer scientists and some programmers. Note: the choice for "program" and not software; code; algorithm; etc is not arbitrary – I think it kind of comprises/implied these other notions. If anyone of you might be interested in this or anything else that is losely or strictly related to history and philosophy of computing and programs, please do share your thoughts/concerns/etc with me. Also: I am currently starting to collect answers from as many people as possible to the main question above and I would be happy to receive some from you too – best wishes, L

    # Tony Cheal 2019-04-29 04:44 #
    Hi everyone! I'm a mathematician of a similar age as @Jonathan Edwards and have programmed since the tail end of the punched card era, mostly at a low level - digging myself upwards from designing and building assemblers, debuggers, compilers, and interpreters to graphical editors (2D and 3D), to web design (frontend and backend).

    I taught Maths and then Computer Science at a Cambridge, UK sixth form and saw the introduction of the BBC Micro. This led me eventually to quitting teaching and writing software for the first ARM-based computer (the Acorn Archimedes) having borrowed one for a weekend to port the virtual machine for an APL interpreter (which could also run on the BBC Micro).

    The (minimal) original website for my company is still up and running (http://www.acecomp.demon.co.uk/) and there's a brief mention of some earlier work on the Binary Dinosaurs site (http://www.binarydinosaurs.co.uk/Museum/icl/tcheal.php). My company merged with two other small UK software houses who produced a HyperCard-like programming system (Genesis) for the Archimedes. I am currently employed by an NLP specialist - designing a new web-based front-end for their product. I have also recently been teaching CS again, now that the UK syllabus has returned to something more like the one I taught in the 1980s.

    I have been working on attempts to improve programming itself for about 25 years, mostly due to a random thought in about 1993 which means I can no longer program without thinking "This could be a lot easier..." every time I hit a key. I've set myself a deadline for September to produce something a bit more public, as a self-imposed incentive. I've probably now gone down most dead-ends, so I'm hoping that failure experience will eventually pay off.

    # nicolas decoster 2019-04-26 13:59 #
    Hi everyone! My name is Nicolas and I live in Toulouse, France.

    I love coding since I first try it (maybe at 11) and do it for a living for more than twenty years (as a computer scientist and a scientist in remote sensing imaging). I like discovering and experimenting new things in computer science. My recent interests are WebAssembly, Vue.js and Rust. Several years ago I cofound "la Compagnie du Code", an organization in Toulouse that organizes workshops to give childrens the opportunity to code and practice creative computing and computationnal thinking. My main tool for that is MIT's Scratch.

    I am convinced that for now programming is a uneccessary complicated and I am wondering how this activity can evolve to permit more people to do it, even those that are not professionnal programmers but that can benefit from a bit of programming every now and then. My guess is that one key thing to bring more people to code is visual coding. So I am here, maybe because on my search on visual programming resources I once heard of Bret Victor, then later found some reference to him in "Future of Coding" and find this initiative very inspiring! :slightly_smiling_face: I know I have lots of stuff to read and discuss to learn what people have expermients in that field...

    So my vision is a visual coding platform on top of web standards. I know there are lots of visual programming semantics that have been invented/experimented since several decades, and it is not new to try to bring people to programming this way, and none has really succeeded (some more than others, but none has became a standard or is widely used). But I am convinced that there is some stuff to experiment! I have started to read some content of futureofcoding.org and what I have read so far is very close to my vision, in particular in https://futureofcoding.org/about#mission where lots of points I should have wrote myself, except that I focus less on low level language, which is important, but for me the first step is the visual parts.

    To conclude, I hope my trip in this slack and with the "Future of Coding" community will make me challenge my thoughts, discover some new inspiring visions and people, and experiment more on that field!

    # Jason Priestley 2019-04-17 08:25 #
    Good morning and hello all. My name is Jason Priestley, I'm a bay area software developer. I have one big idea for the future of software. It's hard to describe because it either sounds vague or trivial or incomprehensible depending on how I describe it, so I'll describe it in a few ways, and perhaps the sum will give a better sense of things.

    My idea is to unify programmer and user. Seen from the programmer's side, this means an IDE that provides the discoverability and rich graphical UI that user's enjoy. Seen from the user's side, this means that their walled-garden "apps" are now part of one big app, they are unknowingly editing code by clicking buttons, and there is a smooth transition between graphical UI and code.

    My idea is to bring the Lisp REPL into the graphical era. Read and Print are text-based primitives. The modern equivalent is a graphical UI that can extend and edit itself. The extension method may resemble Reader macros, but instead of taking over Read at certain syntax, it takes over the whole UI.

    My idea is to make data into code. Lisp made code into data - a function declaration is also a linked list. Data into code means that whenever you are operating on data - editing a TODO list say - you are literally editing code in one big program. Editing your TODO list is a specialized UI that does the exact same thing as opening the TODOs variable in your code editor and typing out your changes manually.

    My idea is to make a universal editor. Instead of one editor and many apps you have one editor that can be changed and customized to take on any behavior.

    My idea is to complete the idea behind Emacs. People joke that Emacs is an OS, that you can do anything in Emacs. I take these jokes seriously. An extensible editor should be our OS, but emacs is too ad-hoc and too tied to text buffers to really suffice. Emacs, but the primitive operations are more low-level UI constructs, and graphical from the start.
    48 comments
    # Dan Cook 2019-04-04 16:22 #
    I'm excited to meet someone who worked at Intentional Software! I've watched videos of Charles Simonyi talk about links in code being stored as strong references, and about generative programming. I don't think think those concepts are foreign to this community, but I was very excited to see a real company (Intentional) formed around doing programming that way. I look forward to whatever insights you can find and provide in this community.

    # Jeremy Penner 2019-04-04 13:04 #
    Hey folks, I'm Jeremy. I'm based in Ottawa, ON, Canada. Been listening to the podcast off and on for a while, don't remember how I found it.
    I've been programming since I was 4 years old using BASIC on a Commodore Vic-20. My career as a developer has been kind of all over the map, but the relevant detail for this crowd is that I got very excited about DSLs in the early 2000s and went to work at Intentional Software for five and a half years (2006-2011).
    I also run a game-making community at glorioustrainwrecks.com, where the guiding ethos is to be creative and expressive without gatekeeping or judgement about your choice of tools, game mechanics, or subject matter. Tiny, weird, and personal games are the norm, to the extent there is a norm. Hyper-accessible game-making tools like Klik & Play and Twine deserve to be talked about in the same breath as Hypercard IMO.
    In general, my main interest at this point is empowering ordinary people; computing should be understandable, accessible, personal, collaborative, and in the direct control of the people who use it. When I was a kid, I was surrounded by tools that were designed to be learnable by people who had never touched a keyboard, and resources that encouraged me that understanding computers was not only possible, but fun and rewarding. To the extent that improving programming can advance that goal, I am on board.

    # Wouter van Oortmerssen 2019-03-27 16:33 #
    Hello, World! I'm Wouter van Oortmerssen and I've made a few programming languages (http://strlen.com/programming-languages/) probably the most futuristic being Aardappel (graphical distributed tree rewriting by example, http://strlen.com/aardappel-language/) and Restructor (fully automatic whole program refactoring, also graphical, http://strlen.com/restructor/). My main project right now is a more conventional language, Lobster, that nevertheless has some innovation (e.g. flow sensitive type specialization, automatic lifetime analysis, FRP-like frame variables etc, http://strlen.com/lobster/). On the sillier side I once caused an esolang revival with http://strlen.com/false-language/. Oh and in my day job I work on LLVM and WebAssembly :slightly_smiling_face: Also make games and game engines, and productivity tools like TreeSheets. Details: http://strlen.com/

    # Shalabh 2019-03-24 23:29 #
    Hi Everyone,

    It was great to meet some of you today at the SF/Dynamicland meetup. While I've
    been on Slack for a bit, I never posted to introductions so here it is.

    I'm a software engineer professionally and over time I've grown increasingly
    dissatisfied with the general state of affairs. It was all fun and games for a
    while, but then I started watching Alan Kay videos :smile:. While digging into
    historical ideas and banging my head against what seem to be a hard ceiling in
    many of the tools and systems we use, I've arrived at the position that there is
    a large space of possibilities that has been left unexplored while we continue
    to incrementally hammer away at the entrenched systems. I believe big leaps can
    only happen if many established fundamental ideas are changed or replaced. For
    instance, we store and share information by encoding it in a
    non-introspectable, very low level medium (aka files) that also loses its
    connections to related information, history and identity. We then redesign these
    features over and over in various ways in different contexts. Programs as text
    files is another poor representation. We re-implement the same functionality and
    schemas in different siloed processes and services. It seems our language for
    interconnection and scaling up is really poor. Much of programming deals with
    stuff that isn't really computing anything but just dealing with represenation
    changes (e.g. parsing - doesn't change the information content). Worse, this
    type of represenation shuffling code is tightly intermingled with the computing
    code. We sit in front of powerful computers, and simulate them in our heads -
    humans are simulating the general purpose simulator.

    So what's an alternative? I don't know but perhaps creating a new
    PL/DB/framework to fit in a PL/DB/framework shaped hole in the current mess may not
    help. We need to explore ideas that are holisitic, ground up rethinking of what
    computing is, how the space is partitioned into concepts and artifacts (note
    files/filesystems, OS processes, databases, 'programs', compilers etc. are all
    means to an end, serving the users achieve some of their goals - what are the
    goals and what other ways can they be expressed?). How does something like this
    'alternative substrate' or 'new material for computing' fit onto the existing
    world? It doesn't, but my interest is more of a research exercise - how can it
    be done, what would make it complete and self sustaining? If we have some good
    ideas, we can prototype. Since this is broad and can go in all directions, I've
    been writing to try and clear my thoughts and keep moving forward in some way.
    If you're interested take a look at https://shalabh.com/programmable-systems/
    # Yoz Grahame 2019-03-24 14:19 #
    (frantically throws together some kind of intro before heading to meet everyone at Dynamicland)

    Hello there! I’m Yoz, a short bald Brit who lives in Oakland and works in SF. I’ve been lurking on this Slack for a while after enjoying a few episodes of Steve’s podcast. Some relevant bits of history:
    1. Ever since I first logged onto LambdaMOO in 1993, I’ve been obsessed with the potential for shared programmable worlds. This led me to 5 years working at Linden Lab, the creators/maintainers of Second Life, Blocksworld and Sansar, all of which are shared programmable worlds like MOO. It taught me a huge amount about the underestimated benefits and problems of these systems.
    2. I spent 4 years at 18F, a consultancy within the US Government. It teaches departments about agile development & procurement, user-centered design and open source, all with the aim of serving citizens better. Most of my time was spent both programming new systems and learning about legacy ones. It convinced me that most of our software development was inherently a bad idea, and that it would be better to build on no-code/low-code systems, and to focus on empowering staffers rather than automating their jobs away.
    3. I’m fascinated by debugging, with existing and new tools. I’ve given talks on debugging (see thread) and played around with creating new debugging tools.
    4. These days I’m something of a software pessimist, to the point where I’m not sure that we should be teaching kids to code at all - at least, not until we are able to sufficiently manage the complexity we create.
    5. I love amazing bug stories - see the thread for a couple, and also for my favourite computing paper.

    Looking forward to meeting and chatting with folks!
    11 comments

    # Robin Allison 2019-03-17 20:52 #
    Hi everyone! My name is Robin Allison. I want to understand stuff. I studied pure math in undergrad and grad school for a year. I studied math because I could get it and obsessed over algebraic topology because more than any other subject because I couldn't get it. That wasn't good for my career but its given me a unique perspective on math and I'm grateful for that. I read Michael Nielsen's essay "Reinventing Explanation" which eventually let me understand Bret Victor. I came to the conclusion that my understanding was limited by the representations we used, and that by inventing my own I could better understand.

    I've had two personal victories, one with spectral sequences and one with the proof of the cellular boundary, in designing better representations using static media. I'm working on better representing the computation of the homology of the projective plane using the decomposition RP^2 = e^2 \cup e^1 \cup e^0, extending the previous techniques. I hope that these "prototypes" can convince other mathematicians the merits and unexplored possibilities of design, leaving aside the possibilities of dynamic media. Additionally I speculate heavily on how we interface with mathematical ideas, motivated by whats probably considered low working memory and expressive language capabilities for math.

    In my experience it is extremely difficult to get other mathematicians to think about the kinds of ideas talked about here. I think part of the problem is that the solution is outside of math whereas for coding at least the solution is still code and has a historical basis in the work of Alan Kay etc. So I hope I can hang out here until mathematics expands to consider "design" a part of math too. :slightly_smiling_face:
    12 comments

    # Tiago Simoes 2019-03-13 05:14 #
    Hi people from the future,

    I'm based in Portugal and I've started working at OutSystems 18 years ago, where we are approaching this opportunity space more from a business side, targeting medium-large companies. Historically it's been hard, as there has been a lot of push-back from the more technical crowd.

    Recently industry analysts (Gartner, Forrester) have discovered there is a big market for these low-code solutions (thanks, in part, to our own effort), and we're riding that wave and have become an Unicorn.

    We've always approached development from a user experience angle, and now we have more and more established usability practices that steer our IDE and our language.

    Looking forward to learn and share, and for the critique of a group that has this subject in their hearts and minds.

    We have a free version that can be tried out at https://www.outsystems.com/

    # Miguel Rochefort 2019-03-03 23:51 #
    Hi everyone!

    My name is Miguel Rochefort. I'm a software developer from Montréal, Canada. I've been traveling around Southeast Asia (Thailand, Vietnam, Malaysia, Bali) for the past 6 months out of my 21-liter backpack.

    I initially got into programming at age 10, when I built my first websites (HTML, CSS, JavaScript). At 12, I started played with Python and C++. At 16, it was Visual Basic and PHP. At 18, I started learning C#, which has been my main language for the past 10 years. I then discovered Haskell, Prolog, Lisp, Smalltalk, ML, Agda, Idris, Coq, Mercury, Eve, etc. That's when I got hooked on programming language design.

    My main influences are Bret Victor, Alan Kay, Douglas Engelbart, Chris Granger, Ted Nelson, Tim Berners Lee, Jef Raskin, Steve Jobs, Stephen Wolfram, Charles Simonyi, David Allen, Mathias Duarte, etc. If I could travel back in time, I would go to Xerox PARC.

    The current state of software is a mess. The incidental complexity is unbelievable. Nothing changed in the past 40 years. We must have reached a local maxima.

    Here are some of my heuristics for the future of programming:

    - Using software and creating software should feel the same.
    - 80% of people should be able to program without any formal training.
    - You should be productive when programming on a 5" phone (but the optimal interface should be VR or R).
    - Programming should not involve text files and syntax.
    - Programming by example (with direct manipulation) should be the dominant paradigm (WYSIWYG, TDD, ML dataset, Excel's Flash Fill).
    - The distinction between natural language, programming language and graphical user interface should disappear.
    - Programming is mainly a modeling problem.
    - Designing and implementing GUI by hand doesn't scale (especially once responsive design considers all of a user's preferences) and should be automated (e.g., Naked Objects).
    - The code to invoke a user (GUI) and the code to invoke a machine (API) should be identical.
    - Every function/predicate/model ever created should be instantly available to everyone.
    - Mechnical turks and AI functions should be as easy to call as a local function.
    - Fuzzy/bayesian values (e.g., "integer between 0 and 18") should be first class citizens, and automatically turn any deterministic functions into a fuzzy/probabilistic functions.
    - Strings should be avoided, and semantically richer types/ontologies (Email, PhoneNumber, Password, Country) should be used instead.

    Right now, I'm experimenting with Quantified Self. I'm trying to collect as much information about my life as I can. This starts with IoT devices, wearables, NFC tags, QR codes, cameras, audio recorders, GPS trackers, keyloggers, IFTTT, manual input, etc. Then I have to manually/automatically classify/quantify the collected data, to extract computable meaning/semantics. Ultimately, I can visualize the data, query it, infer new knowledge, make lifestyle changes to affect the output, etc. The idea is that the more we know about a user, the less we need to ask it for input ("don't make me click") and the less assumptions about it we need to hard code in our code base. I believe this is the first step to make coding against a user as easy as coding against an API or a database.

    I'm looking forward to some great discussions!
    4 comments
    # nagle 2019-03-02 13:17 #

    i spent a few years in bret victor & john maloney's lab groups at harc / ycr (https://harc.ycr.org) and currently "lead" learning & research at coda (www.coda.io)

    i am coming to boston soon and saw the future of coding boston community so wanted to say hello. (based in the east bay.)

    nice to meet you all!

    # Humberto Ayres Pereira 2019-02-27 03:28 #
    @Iridian Kiiskinen @Ilari Kajaste @Ville Ilkkala link?
    4 comments
    # Ilari Kajaste 2019-02-27 03:02 #
    Hi folks! I'm Ilari, a developer at a Finnish startup Valaa Technologies (colleague of Ville and Iridian above :point_up_2:). To be a bit grandiose: We're creating what could be called a new paradigm of web coding, called ValOS (Valaa Open System). In practice it isn't that different from all the black magic things that something like Meteor framework does (automatic live updates to all displayed data between multiple users, etc). But on the background, it is a deeper rethinking of the coding model (especially distribution of code, and the frontend/backend separation), instead of piling more and more stuff on top of current stacks. Anyway, we can discuss our thing more on the channels, but I think it was relevant to intro since it's very relevant for why I am here. Because what we are doing is is directly in the frontlines of the future of coding. I'm happy to talk about this more.

    I've personally been coding from something like age of ten, and I've always been interested in experimenting with things. Professionally I've been a (full-stack) coder for approx. 7 years. I have an educational background in usability, and often call myself a human-geek interface. My personal passions, in addition to coding, are storytelling and games. Hopefully I'll manage to combine all these things at some point. Hopefully soon.

    Currently the stuff I'm most interested in are the possibilities of ValOS resource model, combined with how quick code experimentation with ValOS is. As a coder, I want to both see and use immediate results instead of having to jump through hoops. If I hadn't encountered ValaaTech, I'd be doing similar experimentation with Meteor.
    # Iridian Kiiskinen 2019-02-26 22:56 #
    Hiya. I'm an entrepreneur partner of Ville's and the chief architect of ValOS base infrastructure. I'm more than happy to share deeper technicalities of the stack, but glad to leave Ville do most of the talking.
    I'm a generalist and a systems builder (with all the good and the bad that comes with it), and for me ValOS is an 'exercise' of pushing the envelope of 'Distributed CRUD Event Sourcing' on several fronts as a basis of interactive content sharing and execution environment. The vision crystallized already back in late 2016 and we were able to bootstrap our own IDE 'Zero' for developing itself in late 2017 - this is the point were it ceased to be an exercise but a real thing. While the design has always centered around the base technologies of JS, HTML5 and CSS (and always will be!), the underlying paradigm is quite different. This has meant having to reinvent more wheels than we'd like. But we're on the doorsteps of having a fully functional development ecosystem with all the necessary components in place. So even I am sticking my neck out and not have Ville do all the networking... :stuck_out_tongue:
    # Ville Ilkkala 2019-02-25 09:48 #
    Hi! everyone! I’m Ville Ilkkala from a Finnish startup called Valaa Technologies. We are working on an open source software development architecture called ValOS (Valaa Open System) that is based on sort of an direct manipulation programming and a globally distributed event sourcing mechanism that covers also the application source code, not just the data.

    I am more of an prototype user / citizen developer and I have written my first full-stack applications with the ValOS platform (I never really got my head around existing web development stacks and suffered the most with back ends and databases). Others in our team are working on the core technology and the web IDE. My prior working history includes educational game design, interaction and concept design and other things going on around the code. Since getting my feet wet with programming I have also started teaching it to non-programmers using our platform.

    I learned about futureofcoding.org last year when Steve sent me an bug report that our IDE doesn’t even start. :smile: He interviewed us last week and posted the video on #share-your-work.

    The projects here seem super interesting and inspiring. I look forward to discussions, feedback and meeting new people. :slightly_smiling_face:

    I'm most active in LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/ville-ilkkala-1809b319/
    6 comments
    # David Piepgrass 2019-02-16 18:08 #
    I want to work on the foundations of programming and on interoperability, and I think my work is relevant to everyone here. Many researchers, for instance, have made experimental programming languages and environments - but they can't interoperate with each other! Many languages can only interoperate with C, one of the most archaic languages in existence!

    We must break down these silo walls, so I want to work on those common foundations: to figure out a way to let you write a library in a language that will convert itself to several different languages and run easily on many platforms. To figure out how to standardize everything from point data types (X,Y coordinates), to D-style ranges (an abstraction for subsequences), to whatever data types neural networks are made of, to the way debuggers work. (current thinking: a StackOverflow-like site where people vote on interface designs?). In short, I want to solve the technical problems that create friction in both the niche of programming language design and in the broader world of software engineering. (But, as I say, no time, can't do it. It's funny to have enough urgent work to fill a lifetime, but treat it like a minor hobby to do on weekends sometimes.)

    Oh and Bret Victor inspired me yada yada I invent on principle blah blah. Like the rest of y'all :slightly_smiling_face: But seriously, Bret Victor FTW.

    Twitter: @DPiepgrass Site: david.loyc.net
    7 comments
    # David Piepgrass 2019-02-16 17:48 #
    I’ve been dreaming of making some sort of “ultimate programming language” for over 15 years—but to my surprise, never found any like-minded folks until recently. I registered http://loyc.net/ in 2007 with the idea of making a democratically-extensible compiler with multiple input syntaxes; as time passed it morphed into a set of general ideas for language building. More concretely I wrote the C# parser generator LLLPG and the Lisp-inspired macro system it runs within (it's designed so that the same macro system could support any programming language, I just haven't had time to go beyond C#). But for this group the most relevant thing I've made is LESv2 and LESv3, two simple languages to represent universal syntax trees. I've worked a bit with Jonathan Van der Cruise who made Flame, a compiler-building framework for C#. I learned about Haxe just this year, but I've wanted to build something for several years that would let you write libraries targeting several languages at once. I think I could build something better than Haxe and Cito (Ć) - if only I had some funding and manpower. I’d also be interested in a system for bridging programming languages at run-time so they could communicate seamlessly. For now, I’m too busy at my new job to do anything, including hang out here! (truth be told it's a horrible job and I desperately wish to find something better.) I’ve been bursting with ideas for years and hate being unable to execute on them.

    Links:
    • Loyc trees http://loyc.net/loyc-trees
    • LES http://loyc.net/les <= Use this to prototype new programming languages
    • LLLPG http://ecsharp.net/lllpg
    • LeMP http://ecsharp.net/lemp
    • Flame https://github.com/jonathanvdc/Flame
    • Haxe https://haxe.org
    5 comments

    # Max Desiatov 2019-02-03 08:39 #
    Hi all :wave:
    I'm a developer based in Cambridge, UK. I discovered Future of Coding thanks to @Duncan Woods and especially liked the episode about React history with Pete Hunt. I currently code in TypeScript and Swift, but I've done my first more or less serious coding in my life in Scheme and Tcl. Also had a bit of production experience with Haskell as well. I see there are mentions of music interests and visual programming here, and both topics are quite interesting to me. In my spare time I like poking modular synthesisers in something like Audulus (http://audulus.com)

    I'm currently building a framework inspired by React in pure Swift. I was very excited when React Hooks were announced, so I decided to drop the class-based API altogether and only implement a Hooks API. I still need to implement a few more hooks and host components, but I hope I'm much closer to a point where it can be used for real iOS apps and some other platforms in the future, when more renders are added. You can check out my current progress here if you're interested: https://github.com/MaxDesiatov/Gluon
    If this thing gets any traction, I'd like to build visual developer tools for it in the future.

    Thanks for the podcast and the community, super excited to learn more from you all!
